story:
Our Story 

Samamkāya: The crown of the head, middle of the throat, the perineum, the middle of the knees, ankles and feet...in a plumb line. All the āsana are to be practised (this way) to be in line to the core to experience the infinite that is within. (BKS Iyengar, Astadala Yogamala Vol 7 pg 124)

Samamkāya Back Care & Scoliosis Yoga Collective is a therapeutic, worker-owned yoga studio. Our aim is to make yoga accessible and healing to students of all ages and abilities who are living with back injuries, chronic/acute pain, differently shaped spines/bodies, scoliosis and spinal fusions.

In addition to offering highly specialized therapeutic yoga, we are unique in our business structure. We are the ONLY studio operating as a worker-owned cooperative (that we know of) in NYC. We are the only center dedicated exclusively to back care and scoliosis that is owned and run by our teachers. Our cooperative model allows us to build a collaborative co-created environment with sustainable living wages for our highly trained and talented teacher community.  


Our Services

  • Daily therapeutic back care and scoliosis classes
  • Weekend (and sometimes evening) special workshops and teacher trainings with senior teachers from around the world.
  • Private lessons offered directly by our expert teaching faculty
  • Bodywork 


About Us

Our teachers are some of New York City’s most talented, with extensive and continuous training and experience in yoga for back care and scoliosis, as well as other complementary healing modalities (body mind centering, PT, massage, rolfing.) We offer unique yoga teaching. Our existing student community will recognize many of the same teachers they’ve been studying with at Yoga Union Center for Backcare and Scoliosis, plus some new ones. 


Deborah Wolk has been teaching students with scoliosis and other back conditions since 2000. She is the co-founder and co-director of the successful Yoga Union Center for Backcare and Scoliosis conceived and founded this studio and has handpicked our teacher community. It is her vision to ensure that this new venture will offer the same high quality teaching our students are familiar with, but with a democratic, cooperative model of teacher ownership. More about Deborah. / An autobiographical piece /  The NY Times Article/ A review of Deborah's class

Debby Green has been studying yoga since 1984.  When she encountered Iyengar yoga 10 years later, she realized that she would have to start all over again. Her main teachers are Kevin Gardiner, James Murphy and the late Mary Dunn.  She went to Pune in 2011 to study with the Iyengar family.  She teaches a serious subject with lightness and humor, so that students can enjoy the intensity of Iyengar yoga. Debby is also a certified and gifted Rolfer.  WSJ on Debby Green's private lessons  

Eve Holbrook was drawn to yoga for relief from back pain following a childhood horseback riding injury. She has been practicing for 20 years. In 2001, she began teaching classes at theatre companies in New York City. Since then, Eve completed a two-year teacher-training program at the Iyengar Institute of New York, earned Junior Intermediate One level certification from the Iyengar Yoga National Association of the US and founded of The Nerve of Expression, a community project offering yoga to artists with multiple sclerosis.  She has experience with therapeutic applications of yoga for backcare and scoliosis, has assisted in the medical classes at the Ramamani Iyengar Memorial Institute in Pune, India, and in the Specific Needs class at the Iyengar Institue of New York with Senior Iyengar teacher, James Murphy. More about Eve. 

Rachel Jesien  After moving to New York City to pursue a career in Musical Theater and Dance, Rachel Jesien’s path changed dramatically when complications arose due to her Scoliosis.  She came to the Yoga Union Center for Backcare and Scoliosis to find relief and improve her alignment.  After being so positively influenced by Alison West and Deborah Wolk, she decided to turn her attention to a career in teaching with the hopes of spreading the newfound knowledge and clarity from her own practice. Rachel’s teaching focuses primarily on the individual needs of her students, both in group classes as well as private yoga lessons in Manhattan and New Jersey.  She is a Yoga Union 200 hour RYT with certifications in both Backcare as well as Wall-Rope use. Rachel is also excited to become an Elise Browning-Miller certified Yoga teacher for Scoliosis.  Her approach to teaching is incorporating all of the structural and subtle benefits to both Vinyasa and therapeutic classes.  By applying her extensive dance and performing background as well as ever-curious attitude towards anatomy and therapy, Rachel constructs playful and integrated sequences that strive to promote joy and focus within all of her students.  Follow Rachel on Facebook at Yoga with Rachel Jesien.

Rachel Lynch-John Rachel Lynch-John moved to New York from her native England in 1989. She began practicing Iyengar yoga in 1990 and has assisted her Iyengar teacher, Genny Kapuler, since 2001. Through Genny, Rachel met and began studying with Donald Moyer. Rachel is certified in Embodied Anatomy and Yoga (EAY), Embodied Developmental Movement and Yoga (EDMY) and is an Infant Developmental Movement Educator (IDME) through the School for Body-Mind Centering®. She has assisted Bonnie Bainbridge-Cohen (founder of the School Body-Mind Centering®) and taught in the EAY and EDMY yoga teacher training programs in NYC and Berkeley California.

Frank Ricci - After leaving behind a career in the New York fashion industry, Frank Ricci was ready to find inner peace. What began as a casual yoga practice quickly became his passion, he found his true career calling: to help heal others. Frank received his yoga teaching certificate from Yogasana in Brooklyn, where he began teaching in 2010. Since that time, he has received extensive training in therapeutic yoga, including assisting Deborah Wolk. He studies regularly with his mentors and has had the pleasure and privilege of studying with Donald Moyer in the Yoga Room. In 2011, Frank traveled to India for a 5-week course of study In Iyengar Yoga with Rajiv and Swati Chanchani. Frank's compassionate teaching style draws from Iyengar yoga as well as the Alexander Techique, creating a unique experience that is both encouraging and challenging. 

Miriam (Mimi) Rosetti was diagnosed with scoliosis at age 16. Following 6 months wearing a brace, she underwent corrective surgery fusing a large portion of her spine. Nearly 10 years late, in 2005, while simultaneously pursuing a Masters in Applied Positive Psychology at the University of Pennsylvania and delving into her first yoga teacher training at YogaWorks, Mimi began to reconnect with her scoliosis and the impact of her surgery. Since then, she has apprenticed extensively with Deborah Wolk and is certified as a Yoga for Scoliosis teacher through Elise Browning Miller. Mimi spent January 2011 as a student in the medical class at the Iyengar Institute in Pune, India and is currently in the second year of the teacher training at the Iyengar Institute of New York. Mimi lives in Manhattan with her husband and 2 year old daughter. An interview with Mimi.

Susan Turis holds Intermediate Junior I certification from the Iyengar National Association of the US. It wasneck spasms along with the events of 9/11 that led Susan to begin practicing yoga with Senior Iyengar teacher Mary Dunn in 1999. She has been teaching since 2001. The healing qualities that came from Mary's careful instruction changed her life journey. Susan continues to study and assist weekly with James Murphy in specific needs classes at the Iyengar Institute of New York. Her mission as set forth by BKS Iyengar is that Yoga is for everybody, regardless of physical condition or age. The pinnacle of her study comes during extended visits to Pune, India where classes have been led by B.K.S. Iyengar and Geeta, Prashant and Abhijata Iyengar. Susan was born in Brooklyn and lives there with her husband and three children. She earned a degree in psychology from City University of New York, Brooklyn College and has co-founded businesses in real estate and mortgage and insurance brokerage. More about Susan.

Ashlee Willaman began practicing yoga at the age of 13, just around the same time she was diagnosed with scoliosis. Knowing that yoga kept her back pain at bay, she stuck with the practice for the next 20 years and received her 500 hour teacher training from YogaWorks in 2012. Having been a dancer/athlete since her teenage years, she teaches Yoga for Athletes classes with a focus on backcare. She began assisting Deborah Wolk's Backcare Basics class at YUCBS in early 2014.

Andi Wirz is a native of Switzerland. He found his way to yoga through dance and creative movement. He has been studying and teaching the Iyengar method for the last 20 years. Teachers that have influenced him most are Kevin Gardiner, Robin Janis, Donald Moyer and Genny Kapuler. He also studies yoga with the BMC ® approach with Roxlyn Moret and travels every summer with her to Switzerland to teach workshops. Andreas holds a physical education diploma from the University of Basel, Switzerland. He moved to NYC to pursue a career as a modern dancer. He performed with many modern dance companies and spent half a year in Japan performing with the Swiss mime group "Mummenschanz". More about Andiand read A review of Andi's class.

More of our teachers: Wendy Baranello, Julie Brandwein, Hess Kim


What We Need & What You Get

Our studio is already under construction, in fact, it's nearly finished! We will be open for Grand Opening workshops in December and will begin our regular class schedule in January. Your contributions and advance class card/monthly membership purchases are vital in helping us open our doors. 

Here are some things they will help us do:

  • Finish rope wall and other construction
  • Paint the studio
  • Purchase all of the many props that make our studio so special
  • Help us with marketing expenses so we can reach more people in need of our therapeutic yoga classes
  • Ensure we can cover our rent while we have been/are under construction
  • Start us on secure footing, knowing we can expect to see your precious faces and bodies in class!
Your donations, beyond advance class card/membership purchases, make an enormous difference in our financial security in our opening days.


Other Ways You Can Help

Do you have ideas, suggestions, special skills that you think might be helpful as we are opening our doors? Please reach out to us and let us know!
And please share with your friends and family, even if they don't live in the NYC area. We have many students who travel from around the world to study with our teachers. 

Namaste and thank you for your support!
story_txt:
Our Story 
Samamkāya: The crown of the head, middle of the throat, the perineum, the middle of the knees, ankles and feet...in a plumb line. All the āsana are to be practised (this way) to be in line to the core to experience the infinite that is within. (BKS Iyengar, Astadala Yogamala Vol 7 pg 124)
Samamkāya Back Care & Scoliosis Yoga Collective is a therapeutic, worker-owned yoga studio. Our aim is to make yoga accessible and healing to students of all ages and abilities who are living with back injuries, chronic/acute pain, differently shaped spines/bodies, scoliosis and spinal fusions.
In addition to offering highly specialized therapeutic yoga, we are unique in our business structure. We are the ONLY studio operating as a worker-owned cooperative (that we know of) in NYC. We are the only center dedicated exclusively to back care and scoliosis that is owned and run by our teachers. Our cooperative model allows us to build a collaborative co-created environment with sustainable living wages for our highly trained and talented teacher community.  


Our Services


Daily therapeutic back care and scoliosis classes
Weekend (and sometimes evening) special workshops and teacher trainings with senior teachers from around the world.
Private lessons offered directly by our expert teaching faculty
Bodywork 



About Us

Our teachers are some of New York City’s most talented, with extensive and continuous training and experience in yoga for back care and scoliosis, as well as other complementary healing modalities (body mind centering, PT, massage, rolfing.) We offer unique yoga teaching. Our existing student community will recognize many of the same teachers they’ve been studying with at Yoga Union Center for Backcare and Scoliosis, plus some new ones. 



Deborah Wolk has been teaching students with scoliosis and other back conditions since 2000. She is the co-founder and co-director of the successful Yoga Union Center for Backcare and Scoliosis conceived and founded this studio and has handpicked our teacher community. It is her vision to ensure that this new venture will offer the same high quality teaching our students are familiar with, but with a democratic, cooperative model of teacher ownership. More about Deborah. / An autobiographical piece /  The NY Times Article/ A review of Deborah's class
Debby Green has been studying yoga since 1984.  When she encountered Iyengar yoga 10 years later, she realized that she would have to start all over again. Her main teachers are Kevin Gardiner, James Murphy and the late Mary Dunn.  She went to Pune in 2011 to study with the Iyengar family.  She teaches a serious subject with lightness and humor, so that students can enjoy the intensity of Iyengar yoga. Debby is also a certified and gifted Rolfer.  WSJ on Debby Green's private lessons  
Eve Holbrook was drawn to yoga for relief from back pain following a childhood horseback riding injury. She has been practicing for 20 years. In 2001, she began teaching classes at theatre companies in New York City. Since then, Eve completed a two-year teacher-training program at the Iyengar Institute of New York, earned Junior Intermediate One level certification from the Iyengar Yoga National Association of the US and founded of The Nerve of Expression, a community project offering yoga to artists with multiple sclerosis.  She has experience with therapeutic applications of yoga for backcare and scoliosis, has assisted in the medical classes at the Ramamani Iyengar Memorial Institute in Pune, India, and in the Specific Needs class at the Iyengar Institue of New York with Senior Iyengar teacher, James Murphy. More about Eve. 
Rachel Jesien  After moving to New York City to pursue a career in Musical Theater and Dance, Rachel Jesien’s path changed dramatically when complications arose due to her Scoliosis.  She came to the Yoga Union Center for Backcare and Scoliosis to find relief and improve her alignment.  After being so positively influenced by Alison West and Deborah Wolk, she decided to turn her attention to a career in teaching with the hopes of spreading the newfound knowledge and clarity from her own practice. Rachel’s teaching focuses primarily on the individual needs of her students, both in group classes as well as private yoga lessons in Manhattan and New Jersey.  She is a Yoga Union 200 hour RYT with certifications in both Backcare as well as Wall-Rope use. Rachel is also excited to become an Elise Browning-Miller certified Yoga teacher for Scoliosis.  Her approach to teaching is incorporating all of the structural and subtle benefits to both Vinyasa and therapeutic classes.  By applying her extensive dance and performing background as well as ever-curious attitude towards anatomy and therapy, Rachel constructs playful and integrated sequences that strive to promote joy and focus within all of her students.  Follow Rachel on Facebook at Yoga with Rachel Jesien.
Rachel Lynch-John Rachel Lynch-John moved to New York from her native England in 1989. She began practicing Iyengar yoga in 1990 and has assisted her Iyengar teacher, Genny Kapuler, since 2001. Through Genny, Rachel met and began studying with Donald Moyer. Rachel is certified in Embodied Anatomy and Yoga (EAY), Embodied Developmental Movement and Yoga (EDMY) and is an Infant Developmental Movement Educator (IDME) through the School for Body-Mind Centering®. She has assisted Bonnie Bainbridge-Cohen (founder of the School Body-Mind Centering®) and taught in the EAY and EDMY yoga teacher training programs in NYC and Berkeley California.

Frank Ricci - After leaving behind a career in the New York fashion industry, Frank Ricci was ready to find inner peace. What began as a casual yoga practice quickly became his passion, he found his true career calling: to help heal others. Frank received his yoga teaching certificate from Yogasana in Brooklyn, where he began teaching in 2010. Since that time, he has received extensive training in therapeutic yoga, including assisting Deborah Wolk. He studies regularly with his mentors and has had the pleasure and privilege of studying with Donald Moyer in the Yoga Room. In 2011, Frank traveled to India for a 5-week course of study In Iyengar Yoga with Rajiv and Swati Chanchani. Frank's compassionate teaching style draws from Iyengar yoga as well as the Alexander Techique, creating a unique experience that is both encouraging and challenging. 


Miriam (Mimi) Rosetti was diagnosed with scoliosis at age 16. Following 6 months wearing a brace, she underwent corrective surgery fusing a large portion of her spine. Nearly 10 years late, in 2005, while simultaneously pursuing a Masters in Applied Positive Psychology at the University of Pennsylvania and delving into her first yoga teacher training at YogaWorks, Mimi began to reconnect with her scoliosis and the impact of her surgery. Since then, she has apprenticed extensively with Deborah Wolk and is certified as a Yoga for Scoliosis teacher through Elise Browning Miller. Mimi spent January 2011 as a student in the medical class at the Iyengar Institute in Pune, India and is currently in the second year of the teacher training at the Iyengar Institute of New York. Mimi lives in Manhattan with her husband and 2 year old daughter. An interview with Mimi.


Susan Turis holds Intermediate Junior I certification from the Iyengar National Association of the US. It wasneck spasms along with the events of 9/11 that led Susan to begin practicing yoga with Senior Iyengar teacher Mary Dunn in 1999. She has been teaching since 2001. The healing qualities that came from Mary's careful instruction changed her life journey. Susan continues to study and assist weekly with James Murphy in specific needs classes at the Iyengar Institute of New York. Her mission as set forth by BKS Iyengar is that Yoga is for everybody, regardless of physical condition or age. The pinnacle of her study comes during extended visits to Pune, India where classes have been led by B.K.S. Iyengar and Geeta, Prashant and Abhijata Iyengar. Susan was born in Brooklyn and lives there with her husband and three children. She earned a degree in psychology from City University of New York, Brooklyn College and has co-founded businesses in real estate and mortgage and insurance brokerage. More about Susan.
Ashlee Willaman began practicing yoga at the age of 13, just around the same time she was diagnosed with scoliosis. Knowing that yoga kept her back pain at bay, she stuck with the practice for the next 20 years and received her 500 hour teacher training from YogaWorks in 2012. Having been a dancer/athlete since her teenage years, she teaches Yoga for Athletes classes with a focus on backcare. She began assisting Deborah Wolk's Backcare Basics class at YUCBS in early 2014.
Andi Wirz is a native of Switzerland. He found his way to yoga through dance and creative movement. He has been studying and teaching the Iyengar method for the last 20 years. Teachers that have influenced him most are Kevin Gardiner, Robin Janis, Donald Moyer and Genny Kapuler. He also studies yoga with the BMC ® approach with Roxlyn Moret and travels every summer with her to Switzerland to teach workshops. Andreas holds a physical education diploma from the University of Basel, Switzerland. He moved to NYC to pursue a career as a modern dancer. He performed with many modern dance companies and spent half a year in Japan performing with the Swiss mime group "Mummenschanz". More about Andiand read A review of Andi's class.


More of our teachers: Wendy Baranello, Julie Brandwein, Hess Kim



















What We Need & What You Get

 Our studio is already under construction, in fact, it's nearly finished! We will be open for Grand Opening workshops in December and will begin our regular class schedule in January. Your contributions and advance class card/monthly membership purchases are vital in helping us open our doors. 
Here are some things they will help us do: 
Finish rope wall and other construction
Paint the studio
Purchase all of the many props that make our studio so special
Help us with marketing expenses so we can reach more people in need of our therapeutic yoga classes
Ensure we can cover our rent while we have been/are under construction
Start us on secure footing, knowing we can expect to see your precious faces and bodies in class! 
Your donations, beyond advance class card/membership purchases, make an enormous difference in our financial security in our opening days.
  


Other Ways You Can Help
Do you have ideas, suggestions, special skills that you think might be helpful as we are opening our doors? Please reach out to us and let us know!
And please share with your friends and family, even if they don't live in the NYC area. We have many students who travel from around the world to study with our teachers. 


Namaste and thank you for your support!

story:
Summary

Sport plays an important and vital role in the social, cognitive and physocal development of children.   The North Ryde Dockers are an Australian Rules Football club that provides the opportunity for players from 5 years of age to 17 years of age to participate in AFL football.  The club has a culture of inclusion and has developed strong community links with families and other local community organisations.  Not being an affluent club we rely on fundraising activity to ensure we can continue to provide our young players with the equipment and facilities to develop in the game and learn strong life skills.   We are staffed by volunteers and we need your help to continue our work.

What We Need & What You Get

The club provides a variety of major and entry levels of sponsorship and corporate engagement opportunities. 

Funds raised through sponsorship will be directed towards, promoting participation in the local community, sporting equipment, development and training and club facilities.  All funds are directly focussed on enhancing the experience and development of young footballers.

Sponsorship opportunities include;

· Major Sponsor (Jumper Sponsorship) - 5 years commitment

· Goal Post Sponsors

· BBQ Sponsor

· Associate Sponsors

· Club Ambassador

The Impact

Play is an important and fundamental right in Childhood.  

Sport and play help a child develop cognitive function, social skills, explore, invent, express their emotions and gain confidence and self respect.   With our busy lifestyle and other social barriers, for many children the chance to learn and grow through sport is not readily available robbing them of some of the most important experiences in childhood.   

Local community sporting clubs and their volunteers provide a vital and important role in the development of children providing effective and safe access to play and physical exercise.   This role can not be undervalued however the access to financial support for clubs like the North Ryde Dockers is often non-existent.  

You have an opportunity to support this vital role and get something back at the same time.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    While we have created various levels of sponsorship that means almost everyone can participate and give back, we understand that not everyone is in a position to do this.  There are many other ways you can help and the most important is to spread the word among your personal and corporate friends via email, Facebook and other vehicles, the important thing is to make a lot of noise!

story: Our son Devin started playing baseball at the age of 7.  We signed our kids up to keep them active and focused.  Little did we know then that he would aspire to the baseball player he is today.  Devin's coach approached us at the first game he played at 7 years old and told us he had natural ability.  He was put on the mound to pitch and has been there since.  When he is not on the mound he is at first base.  Over the last seven years he has trained hard and it has payed off.  Last year he tried out for the Under Armour Baseball Factory and made it.  He attended training and competition at Pirate City in Florida last November with the Baseball Factory.  They would like for him to come back for training and competition again this year.  The cost of the session is $2,000.  This has come however, at the same time as another wonderful opportunity.  While attending a summer camp Devin was approached by the Coach of Gloucester Catholic High School who asked him to join their team.  The baseball program at this school is ranked in the top 5 nationally.  The opportunity is tremendous, but there is added expense for the private education and associated fees for baseball.  He was awarded partial scholarship but this did not cover other essentials like uniforms, travel, books, etc.   Devin has a work ethic like none I have ever seen in a 14 yr old boy.  He eats a healthy diet, works out, trains hard, is a team player and has a heart of gold.  There is never "I" with Devin.  He believes in encouraging and helping everyone.  I'd hate for his hard work to be wasted because we couldn't afford it.  We have worked extra hours to save what we could and now have to reach out and ask for some help.  Please feel free to research the Baseball Factory and Gloucester Catholic.  Every penny donated will be used for Devin's expenses.  Thank you for any support.  Any donation will help:)

story:
The Challenge

30 teams competing in a gruelling 2 day physical and mental challenge in the searing heat of the Qatar desert, in aid of the Action On Diabetes partnership.

The exact details of the challenge are a closely guarded secret until the start of the event on 17th/18th November, but we have been told to prepare for running, swimming, kayaking, and camel riding.

Further details of the challenge can be found at www.maerskoilandqpchallenge.com

Our Team

The Williams Advanced Engineering team is formed of the following 5 members:

  • Damien Scott
  • Sara Khorasani
  • Max Renault
  • Raffat Zreik
  • Gavin Ferguson

What We Need From You

Any donation, large or small.

The entry requirement for the challenge is to raise $5,000. However, Williams Advanced Engineering has kindly donated half, thereby leaving us with $2,500 to raise.

We are comitted to entering so if we fall short of our target we will personally make up the difference.

The Impact Of Your Donation

Every 7 seconds, someone somewhere dies from diabetes.

The full $5,000 entry fee goes to the Action On Diabetes partnership, to help fund awareness, prevention, and management of diabetes.

Further details can be found at www.action-on-diabetes.qa

Other Ways You Can Help

Make some noise to get the word out about our campaign, and encourage others to visit this website.

story:
So, I am unsure where to start.  As some of you may know, I have been very sick for about 4+ years.  For those that do not know, I developed an infection that got into my bloodstream.  This caused damage to my heart and eventually led to Congestive Heart Failure.  I also have high blood pressure, diabetes, COPD, I am on oxygen 24/7 and a CPAP at night.  I take 16 different medications every day just to keep me alive.
 
To further complicate things, I am in constant pain, which makes walking, sitting and even breathing very difficult.  I must use a power chair to get around when I can go outside.  With that said, I am grateful for the chance to get out in the world again in my chair; however, I am now having some vision problems (due to the diabetes) so it is hard for me to see to ride and, as a result, I stay inside.  I was a computer ‘geek’ until earlier this year when my sight became so bad I can’t even see my computer screen. 

Those that have been around me know that I have always enjoyed working including six years owning my own business, fifteen years working for NAPA Auto Parts, 8-1/2 for an Air Cargo Sales Company in Accounting/IT and Management  and 3-1/2 doing accounting for an Environmental Company.  Between 2000 and 2005 I owned my own Cargo Sales Company here in Charlotte.  This business failed due to 9/11 and we made no money for four years.  As of 2008, I can work no longer.  Why does all this matter?  I am not able to get Disability due to the years I was self-employed.  Social Security says I don’t have enough “quarters” in the five years before my disability to qualify.  After multiple chats with lawyers, they have all confirmed that there is nothing that can be done.  All of this has caused tremendous financial strain on our lives.  With my medical bills, pharmacy costs, co-pays and the rising prices of everything, our financial situation is grim.
 
I am not someone who would normally ask for help as I have always wanted to be the one giving; unfortunately, though, I need some help.  We (my wife and I) are trying our absolute best every day.  We have sold most things of value in our home, but still can’t keep up.  We do not have credit cards, mostly doctor / medical bills, prescriptions and normal life things like groceries.  We are no longer able to meet our bills with only my wife’s modest salary, so I am here asking for help.  With all of our expenses, we are running very short every month and I need to raise some funds to enable us to keep our home. 

Our need is about $15.000.00 dollars and my HOPE is to raise whatever possible.  Doing so would allow us to pay my medical bills as well as keep our home.  We would file bankruptcy, but the doctors have to be paid or they will no longer allow us service.
Please remember that any assistance you can give is certainly appreciated, more than we can ever express!

I am using PayPal for all financial ‘gifts’ which means that your payment is secure.  Here are instructions if you do not have a PayPal account:
You can contribute to a campaign via PayPal, even if you do not have a PayPal account. Use your credit card to "Pay as a Guest" without signing in:
1.   When you get to the PayPal screen, you'll see up top "Choose a Way to Pay"
2.   Select the second option: "Pay with a debit or credit card"
3.   Complete the form - PayPal accepts Visa, MasterCard, Discover, and American Express
4.   Deselect the check box that says: "Save this information with a PayPal account"
5.   Click "Review and Continue" to continue with a payment using a credit card
6.   Click on the "Continue Without Logging In" link

  If you are unable to help (we certainly understand) and we thank God for your consideration; but, maybe you know someone who can help?  If so, please pass this link on to them.  Any assistance is greatly appreciated and our thanks to all of those that help in some way. 

Home baked cookies are available if you call ahead or stop by to visit us in South Carolina.

All Our Love,
Cole and Kate

story:
Short Summary

Did you know that 20 million parents of diabetic kids worry EVERY SINGLE NIGHT if their child will be alive in the morning?

Can you imagine that? Sleeping with that fear?

Balancing insulin against food, prior insulin doses, exercise, stress, illness, hormones and many other factors, is an unrelenting, stressful guessing-game.

And to make matters worse, insulin dosing is a best guess – even for doctors.

As a result, 78 million insulin-using adults also fear modifying their doses and their routine.

The current solution consists of

  • an expensive $5000 Continuous Glucose Monitor, with a sensor that pierces the skin for 3-7 days (ouch!)
  • an expensive $8000 Insulin Pump, with a tube that pierces the skin for 3 days (ouch again!).

The alternative? Waking up through the night for blood tests, or hoping for the best. Guesswork. Paper and pen.

ManageBGL solves the overnight problem, by accurately predicting dangerous low blood sugar levels eight hours ahead. This is a world first, with 2 provisional patents granted and 7 more to follow.

ManageBGL solves the dosing problem, by calculating doses and tracking prior insulins, exercise, food etc, and using prediction to determine which doses were incorrect, and fixing them.

Currently we use a high-end server to perform the sophisticated calculations required.

Next we need a native app running directly on smart phones and tablets, with the ability to run offline - in a plane, overseas, and without an internet connection.

Let's make it an app!

Sample prediction trace (Note, this is NOT from a $5000 CGM!):

All the curves are predictions. Orange circles are actual blood tests, blue shading is the ideal zone, the dark blue line is the blood sugar target, the green bar is 'now' - everything to the right is a prediction. 

 We also provide, for the first time, INSTANT SHARING of everything - blood sugars, insulin and carbs - as well as predictions. This makes it far easier for everyone from grandparents to teachers to manage diabetic kids properly.

What We Need & What You Get

All the features we describe here are already done. Currently, the ManageBGL website is only available on phones with an internet connection - but it needs to work in planes, overseas and out of coverage areas, such as in buildings.

  • We need $30,000 to make medical-grade native apps that are beautiful, fast, easy-to-use, and patient-centric, not doctor-centric, which will work both online and offline. 
  • This awesome native app for iOS AND Android will provide:
    • Dose calculation, with fat and protein too
    • Precision tracking of insulin remaining
    • Prediction of blood sugars for the next 8 hours, giving confidence when sleeping, going out etc
    • Suggestions for dose changes (that are not phrased in legal-ese)
    • Instant sharing of ALL data from school to work/home or to any number of carers (Pull, not Push - it doesn't badger everyone with your numbers)
    • Handles families with multiple people with diabetes easily
    • Points! The most comprehensive points system ever designed to help track progress. Parents can convert points to financial rewards, iTunes vouchers, or whatever makes sense to their family
    • Log everything. 38 different logs, from blood sugars, insulin, carbs, eye tests, 3 different levels of exercise, stress, illness etc
    • Integrate data from 60 different meters, pumps and CGMS devices
    • Extensive food database for new foods

    • Integration of information from Personal Health Devices like Fitbit, JawBone, FuelBand, Shine, TicTrak, FitBit, Validic and more

    • Reporting and more.

  • If we don't reach our entire goal, we will develop the apps first, and apply compliance and clinical trials progressively
  • You can choose how you'd like to support us - from a Founder listing, a discounted ManageBGL account and more!
  • Be the first person at work with our limited edition 'Duck Fiabetes'/ManageBGL mug!

    (This is not a typo! Swap the initial letters)

      The Impact

      • Diabetes affects 382 million people worldwide. As an app, ManageBGL will deliver similar health outcomes to an $8000 insulin pump and $5000 CGM (Continuous Glucose Monitor) but at exceptionally low cost - worldwide, not just to first-world countries.
      • With the ManageBGL app and our prediction system, we can maximize the time that a person's blood sugars spend 'in-range', reducing nasty long term complications like blindness, kidney failure, amputation and stroke, and the huge public health costs associated with these, which we all end up paying for.
      • ManageBGL gives people with diabetes confidence to sleep at night with a much higher certainty that they will be alive in the morning.
      • ManageBGL is also very useful for people who are not aware when their blood sugar is low - hypoglycaemic unawareness
      • One in twenty diabetics under the age of 40 who die in their sleep die of an unknown cause. Low blood sugar is suspected (ie insulin overdose), but is hard to prove because blood sugar drops after death. We reduce this risk.

      Testimonials

       Apart from Lucy and myself, ManageBGL is already helping over 1000 others!

      • Before this program, I had no way to predict the impact of insulin and food on my blood glucose levels...I could not manage the math to keep up with how my body was changing to the sensitivity of the insulin. This program is fantastic. I am able to predict highs & lows, and adjust my sensitivity based on time of day....needed to aggressively manage diabetes. It is awesome and should be in all the doctor office recommendations. I am lowering my A1C and aggressively fighting this disease everyday - Cindy Coates Hickory, North Carolina USA
      • Bob is an insulin dependent diabetic – LADA version. And we are both very interested in anything that would make hypos easier to avoid.  We’ve seen enough of the interior of hospital emergency department!"

      Expertise

      • I've had Type 1 diabetes for 24 years, and am the parent of a child with Type 1 diabetes, diagnosed at age 2 (now 9). I understand the difficulties schools and carers have, and ManageBGL is designed to address these
      • I have an Honours degree in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. I am the software architect and CEO of DataMystic; we have spent the last 14 years producing tools for data conversion, data mining and analytics, as well as building and operating websites with huge numbers of users (DownloadPipe), customer billing systems for major energy retailers, and data warehouses for pharmaceutical companies.
      • As a person with diabetes, and the parent of a child with diabetes, I understand what patients want - which can be quite different to what doctors want. Diabetes is perhaps the only disease where the doctor prescribes a drug, but doesn't specify how much to have or when to take it. ManageBGL puts these tools in the hands of the patient for the first time, and empowers them to improve their life in a way no doctor can.

      Awards

      • December - presented ManageBGL to doctors at the World Diabetes Congress in Melbourne. Doctors arrived saying 'I don't believe you can predict', and left saying 'that is a Really Clever Idea'.
      • November - won selection to attend the 2013 Diabetes Mine innovation congress at Stanford University, CA. 
      • August - invited to join the Melbourne chapter of SLP - Startup Leadership Program - an entrepreneur group.

      Extension Goals

      With your help we can extend our goals!

      • Regulatory approval ($10,000) - FDA, TGA (our local authority in Australia), all require registration fees for medical device software. This also ensures that there are feedback mechanism from customers to ensure any problems in the market are ironed out as soon as possible.
      • Clinical trials ($100,000) - doctors need an evidence base before they will support any new solution.

      What About Other Diabetes Apps?

      Current Diabetes Apps cannot distinguish expected high blood sugars from unexpected ones. ManageBGL's predictions provide the context for analysing data and fixing doses - if you did not know what you expected to happen, how on earth can you fix it?

      Delivery Date

      We expect to have an early-stage minimal feature app available for both iOS and Android in early April, and we will add features progressively with projected completion by 1 June.

      Questions and Answers

      Are you taking orders internationally?

      Due to worldwide interest we have included international shipping!

      Which phones will ManageBGL support?

      We will have BOTH an iPhone app and Android app web dashboard at launch. 

      Is my data safe?

      We already use https encryption for the ManageBGL website, and we are currently implementing a HIPAA/HiTech compliance program that will ensure all personal health data is protected to the fullest extent possible. Read more.

      Other questions?

      Please email us at crowd@ManageBGL.com

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Everyone knows a diabetic (or two!):

      • Please tell everyone you know - diabetics and non-diabetics alike - help us to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
      • And please remember to use the Indiegogo share tools at the top!

      Yours very truly,

       

      Lucy Carter (9 years old), with Type 1 diabetes since 2 years old
        Her Dad Simon Carter, with Type 1 diabetes for 25 years
           382 million people with diabetes worldwide.

story:
We saved 18 lives in Siliguri, West Bengal in one week!

We are PINCC, Prevention International: No Cervical Cancer, a group of volunteers that are saving women's lives from cervical cancer in 7 developing countries.

We've started work in this rural town in India where women work on tea plantations, hand-picking tea for $2 per day. There is nowhere to get a gyn exam, and cervical cancer rates are high. We are training health workers to provide cervical screening using plain vinegar, then give same-day treatment to the 10% of women that have pre-cancer, saving their lives. We need to raise $5,000 to bring our team back in April, and donate the exam and cryotherapy equipment to continue this great project. The Sumita Cancer Society here has pledged to carry out screening and treatment visits every week.


For Sushila, we were too late...

When we examined this 38-year-old, she already had invasive cancer which had spread. We sent her to a government hospital, but over half such cases are fatal, even if they can afford treatment.


Will you help us raise the funds to prevent these terrible deaths?

Donate on Indiegogo, to help spread the word, and give to our work.

story:
Hello :-) My name is Loren. 

I am a trans* person in need of some help financing my transition. I am about to move to NYC to start grad school and have to take out quite a few loans for that so I am extremely pressed for money. That is why i started this fundraiser, bc i really need people's help if im going to be able to finally get top surgery. And i really dont want to have to wait years and years and years.

Right now im trying to first reach the $500 mark bc with that I can have my first appointment with Garramone and set a date for my surgery. 

Eventually the surgical and pathology fees will total $5,200 and the hospital and anasthesia fees will total $1,300. 

So I need a total of 6,500. Which is more money than I have ever had! So please help me if you can! It means so much to me! Any amount helps and is super amazing and super appreciated!

And if you know of anyone else who would donate, please spread the word.

Thank you! :-D

story:
About Me

Hi! My name's Caitlin (McGrory). My dream is to get my 500-hour Yoga Teacher Training. 

I am currently in India and 500 hour Teacher Trainings are much more affordable than in the United States. However, I still don't have the budget for it after paying a LOT of money in medical expenses in the West prior to coming here and as in the past, not getting anywhere but diagnoses and lifetime ailment talk.

So I turn back to yoga, again. With more devotion. 

In the spirit of energetic give-and-take, I'm happy to offer astrology chats about your life, goals, karmic history/ "autopilot" moods and behaviors, and gifts to claim and growth to be had by clearing out those old issues or limiting beliefs or fears that get projected onto 2013. :)

What We Need & What You Get

By donating anything you'll get a huge invitation, warm welcome and free/discount to a class I teach in the future. 

Donating anything is really super appreciated.

In return for contributing larger amounts, you will receive astrology life path/soul intention chattings in the paradigm of Evolutionary Astrology and Transpersonal Psychology.

The Impact

I'm hopeful about this! I'd love to become 500 hour certified and be able to have a space one day and make yoga accessible to a lot of people that could benefit from it.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can’t contribute, but if you'd like you can help in other ways:

  • Get the word out by sharing on Facebook or telling your friends! :)

Thanks so much!!!!!

Caitlin

story:
The Skinny

I'm a trans woman, and I've been lucky so far in my transition. A lot of things fell into place for me to make it possible, and even fairly successful. I've been very fortunate to have friends and family support me emotionally and even financially at many different times during the process. I not only survived, I've thrived in ways I didn't think possible when I first approached this.

Last year, I fought for and won arbitration with my employer for coverage of surgery vital to my transition, Gender Reassignment Surgery (GRS). I scheduled my surgery with a well known surgeon in the field as soon as I was able, and preauthorized for the whole thing. The waiting list was long, and my date is coming up in September. Now that I'm here, I've hit a road block.

Financial obligations have made it impossible for me to save enough money to travel and stay in the area. I need you to help me fund this.

The Pretzel Monies

(If you don't get this reference, it's a classic Simpsons Episode: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fayTpKCQd5M)

I need around $1,500 to fund my trip at a minimum. This includes a cross-country flight, accommodations, local travel (I'll need to take cabs back and forth due to my surgery), and food. Due to the severity of the recovery, I need to stay in the area for around 10 days post-operation, and one night prior.

A cross-country flight from NY to CA will run me around $350. My hotel or other accommodation options are around $1,000+. The more money I'm able to raise, the better my options will be, and closer to my Doctor's office/hospital. I set my goal lower to try to help increase my chances of a successful fundraiser, but at this level, it won't bring me up to where I need to be.

While I'm there, I'll still have a paycheck coming from my job, so I should be able to handle surprises and any extras that always seem to surprise you. That said, having a buffer will be very helpful.

Any amount will help me reach my goal, no matter how small.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help me out financially with this, perhaps you can share my campaign with others who might? Helping a stranger isn't always easy, but you're still making a tremendous impact on someone's life.

Thank you all - this means more to me than you can imagine.

story:
If you’re a pet owner, sooner or later you will experience the fear and anxiety of having your companion go missing. Let’s be honest, even taking the best precautions and care, sooner or later your pet will wander away. Now, suppose there was a simple-to-use, inexpensive system you could depend on to monitor your pet’s location, warn you when they’ve wandered away from your  “safety zone”, and lead you to them quickly before they get in harm’s way? Would such a system give you peace of mind, knowing that your pet is safe? Well, that system is available now and it is already being used by pet owners from Florida to Oregon. It's Marco Polo, and we're the company that invented it.

 

See Marco Polo in Action

Seeing is believing. So take a couple minutes to watch Marco Polo in action in some real-world situations. In the following video you can see for yourself how simple and intuitive Marco Polo is to use.

 

 

What Are Others Saying?

We’ve been field testing Marco Polo for many months, in all sorts of terrains, weather conditions and situations. Put simply, Marco Polo works! But don’t just take our word for it, read what our users are saying. Many of them have found their lost pets quickly and easily, and brought them home safe and sound. They are Marco Polo believers.

 

 

 

 

 

Participate Now

For a limited time we are offering Marco Polo systems only through our Indiegogo campaign. If you buy now you will receive the earliest delivery of the first production units. These are just like the systems we have been successfully field testing for many months, identical to the systems used bring Bailey, Buck, Katella and many other pets home to their owners. And the best part of all, this price is 25% off list price.

These units are on order from the factory and will be delivered in August. For early birds you can order a one pet system as shown in the picture below for $165 or a two pet system for $235.

To order now and lock in this special pricing just make your selection below:

  • If you’re quick, you can click in the Perks area at the right to get the “Early Bird Single Pet Special” at $165 before the limited supply runs out.
  • Single Pet Systems are still a great deal at $180, even if the early bird specials sell out. Click in the Perks area and get the “Single Pet Special”.
  • Have two pets you want to protect? Easy, just on the appropriate Perk in the area at the right to get our $235 Early Bird Special Two Pet System pricing.
  • If you missed out on the Early Bird Two Pet System, never fear. There are still systems available at a great price. Just click on the Perk at the right to get our special $250 price on a two pet Marco Polo System.

 

System Perks

Perks which include a Marco Polo System will consist of a complete system, new, in our standard end user packaging (see photo below).

The photo below shows the contents of the inside of the package:

  • Marco Polo hand held Locator
  • Tag (good for one pet or other object)
  • Charger (charges tags or locators)
  • User Reference Booklet and a Quick Start Guide (not shown). The Quick Start Guide is printed on heavy card stock so you can easily carry it with you.

 

You can always add additional tags (up to three pets protected by one locator). Additional collar tags can be purchased on our website once we receive our production order from the factory.

story_txt:
If you’re a pet owner, sooner or later you will experience the fear and anxiety of having your companion go missing. Let’s be honest, even taking the best precautions and care, sooner or later your pet will wander away. Now, suppose there was a simple-to-use, inexpensive system you could depend on to monitor your pet’s location, warn you when they’ve wandered away from your  “safety zone”, and lead you to them quickly before they get in harm’s way? Would such a system give you peace of mind, knowing that your pet is safe? Well, that system is available now and it is already being used by pet owners from Florida to Oregon. It's Marco Polo, and we're the company that invented it.
 
See Marco Polo in Action
Seeing is believing. So take a couple minutes to watch Marco Polo in action in some real-world situations. In the following video you can see for yourself how simple and intuitive Marco Polo is to use.
 

 
What Are Others Saying?
We’ve been field testing Marco Polo for many months, in all sorts of terrains, weather conditions and situations. Put simply, Marco Polo works! But don’t just take our word for it, read what our users are saying. Many of them have found their lost pets quickly and easily, and brought them home safe and sound. They are Marco Polo believers.
 

 
 

 
 
Participate Now
For a limited time we are offering Marco Polo systems only through our Indiegogo campaign. If you buy now you will receive the earliest delivery of the first production units. These are just like the systems we have been successfully field testing for many months, identical to the systems used bring Bailey, Buck, Katella and many other pets home to their owners. And the best part of all, this price is 25% off list price.
These units are on order from the factory and will be delivered in August. For early birds you can order a one pet system as shown in the picture below for $165 or a two pet system for $235.
To order now and lock in this special pricing just make your selection below:

If you’re quick, you can click in the Perks area at the right to get the “Early Bird Single Pet Special” at $165 before the limited supply runs out.

Single Pet Systems are still a great deal at $180, even if the early bird specials sell out. Click in the Perks area and get the “Single Pet Special”.

Have two pets you want to protect? Easy, just on the appropriate Perk in the area at the right to get our $235 Early Bird Special Two Pet System pricing.

If you missed out on the Early Bird Two Pet System, never fear. There are still systems available at a great price. Just click on the Perk at the right to get our special $250 price on a two pet Marco Polo System.

 


System Perks
Perks which include a Marco Polo System will consist of a complete system, new, in our standard end user packaging (see photo below).
The photo below shows the contents of the inside of the package:

Marco Polo hand held Locator


Tag (good for one pet or other object)


Charger (charges tags or locators)


User Reference Booklet and a Quick Start Guide (not shown). The Quick Start Guide is printed on heavy card stock so you can easily carry it with you.

 
You can always add additional tags (up to three pets protected by one locator). Additional collar tags can be purchased on our website once we receive our production order from the factory.

story:
Scott Mosen

Scott is trying to raise $1500 for the heart foundation and I would like to help him.

He is and amazing person who has been through more than he should have, he came to my school recently and gave a talk - about him and his family - and told us that he was trying to raise the money. I decided to help and I would love you to as well.

What We Need & What You Get

Although with this campain there are no perks as such there is one thing that you can think of, you will have helped many people to overcome deadly and painfull ailments.

I have not set an exact amout that is needed any amout is welcome and also very appreciated.

In case you're wondering, I am using my Dad's Indiegogo account to do this.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cant donate to this please share this story and page to as many people as you can (I want to get this out as much as possible).

Cut and paste the following into twitter or facebook or whereever you share:-

Help Scott raise $1500 for the Heart Foundation, please share and donate if you can http://www.indiegogo.com/Help-Hearts?a=985037 via @inkletblot

 

Thank you.

story:
Our Story

At Green Bag Lunch, we want to bring kids a healthy, whole foods alternative to pink slime and mystery meat. Our idea is to offer homemade bag lunches for those kids whose parents don't have time to make it themselves, but want to insure a well balanced meal to get them through the day. We will focus on local, organic products when available, and allow a certain level of customization to suit the needs of the children. In addition to the lunches, we will also offer organic baby food and take home meals for the family.

I am a father of three awesome little boys and a chef of twenty years. I am just really tired of the food that kids are served in school, but realize that many people don't have time to do it themselves every day.

 

The Impact

The impact of our company is simple; it helps families. It helps children eat better and feel better and gives parents more time to spend with their families.

 

What We Need & What You Get

What we need to get started is a location, equipment and marketing. We need to be able to find a location that will enable us to get our product out there. We need a steamer, deck oven, mixer, food processer and many small wares. To be successful we have to brand ourselves, including getting a logo and pasting it on everything. We are going to shoot for using all recycled and biodegradable products and using sustainable practices, we know this is the right thing to do, it just costs a little more to get started.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our campaign with everyone; send us words of encouragement, anything helps! Good vibes, happy thoughts, positive energy and prayers are also appreciated!

story:
The Trip

The purpose for this trip is to spread the teachings of Kundalini Yoga and Meditation as taught by Yogi Bhajan and participate in volunteer work for communities involved in sustainable and eco-conscious projects.
I am currently working to secure my place as a volunteer on an organic farm, as well as book Kundalini Yoga workshops at local yoga centers. Will keep you updated on the  progress.

The Impact

My mission is to connect with and uplift the Bulgarian community. The long term goal is to spread the teachings of Kundalini Yoga as taught by Yogi Bhajan through classes and workshops across the country.

What We Need 

The donated funds will go towards airfare and stay in Bulgaria. Approximately $3,500 for 3 weeks.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread the word by sharing this with friends and family.

Begin a daily yoga practice.

Commit to doing seva (selfless service) in your community.

story:
Please take the time to read Brads story below.  We need your help to send Brad to Nationals, every little bit counts, and we are so thankful to share this rare opportunity with you. The school Brad attends does not financially support these athletes past the OFSSA level and Brad is hoping to raise $3000 to offset his cost to compete.


All money graciously donated will go directly to Brad and his coach to cover the cost of competing in nationals.  This includes air fare, car rental, hotel accommodations, registration fees, and meals.

 Hi, my name is Brad Davis and I represented Bayside Secondary School for this past 2014 Cross Country Season.  Throughout my 2 years of running, I have represented Bayside and have shown my true potential under pressure. I have won 7 Bay of Quinte titles, 6 COSSA titles, and 1 bronze and 1 silver medal in the Eastern Ontario championships. Recently at the OFSAA level of competition (all of Ontario), I placed 6th in the 1500m this past track season and 8th out of 300 during this past fall. Through all of my success, there is only one person to thank. That person is my coach, Dan Tripp. Although during my first year of running, Tripp and the rest of the teaching staff were unable to coach their students or participate in any extra-curricular activities, Tripp found a loop hole and found a way to coach myself and my training partners. Before I started running, I had myself mixed into what you would call a “bad crowd”. I wasn’t exactly the child I was raised to be. Throughout my Grade 9 year in high school, I made some poor choices.  During grade 9, I was 5’7” tall and weighed 160lbs.  I was constantly made fun of and bullied on a daily basis. One day, I woke up and wasn’t feeling too well.  I thought I had just caught a bad flu. It turned out that I had caught a sickness that caused me to miss a total of 25 consecutive days of school. I had lost 35 pounds. I started to like the way I looked so I started working out and going for nightly jogs. Once I started jogging, I felt more confident. For gym class, we ran what is called the “beep” test.  Since I had been jogging as often as I could, I was in good enough shape to get a strong score. Mr. Tripp was doing recruiting for the cross country team and he somehow saw something in me and tried to convince me to run on the Bayside Cross Country Team. I liked his offer but wasn’t sure I wanted to be one of those guys who ran around in circles with short shorts and over exposing themselves. Later that day a girl (who i thought was cute but was shy) came to me and said I should join as well.  I finally, through her motivational words and kind guidance, decided to join the Cross Country Team. I went to my first cross country practice and I loved it. Although I wasn’t the best and there were two other guys that were way better than me, I enjoyed the atmosphere and support that everyone gave. As I progressed in the running world, I learned the ways of the other runners and wanted to be the best on the team. All I wanted from running was to win a race. Unfortunately, I didn’t win any races that cross country season but that soon changed.  I trained all winter long and at the Track Season 2012, I won 7 straight races and I finally got my gold medal. Going into OFSAA track for the first time, I found myself too inexperienced and didn’t believe that there was any possibility that I would get a top 3 finish. When I came out of the 1500m finals with a 10th place finish, I wasn’t satisfied. So I trained my guts out all summer on the track and on trails at Zwicks park with my coach. Two of my team mates left for university and others had other commitments that they couldn’t make it out to practices, so it was just Mr. Tripp and myself most of the time. Getting to know Mr. Tripp (aka Tripp) and his accomplishments impressed me greatly. He was always there for me to pick me up off the ground when i didn’t think I could run another step. Somehow he always gets a little bit extra out of me. Tripp knows I love to prove everyone wrong. He will motivate me using the things he knows that get under my skin to get me to give it that little bit extra that I didn’t even know I had in me. Tripp is the reason I still run.  He is one-of-a-kind.  In the spring of 2014, Tripp was notified that he was one of the teachers that would be losing their jobs due to government cuts.  The whole school was devastated to know that this incredible teacher, mentor and coach would not be returning to Bayside for the 2014-2015 School year.  But nothing stops this man.....even though through a tough loss of his job, he still makes it out to practices to train the team and myself and makes it out to the important meets so he is there for us. He makes sure his voice is heard everywhere along the course when we are running.  He always gives the team or myself what I like to call the “Tripp Talk” which is basically a motivational speech before every race that will calm the nerves and get you focused on the more positive things. Tripp is the biggest and best role model any kid my age could ask for. He has brought me up to the athlete and person I am today. I continue to learn from him and follow his footsteps as the years go by.

Why I want to go to Nationals?

To go to Nationals in Vancouver will give me the opportunity to show my true colours against the best in the whole country. If I place in the top 7, I will make my first Team Canada which means I will get to participate against the best the world has to offer which has always been my dream.  Competing at Nationals is my next goals.  My ultimate dream is to go to the Olympics and Nationals will be one of the milestones to get me closer to my dream. Every night, I lay in my bed and imagine myself running against the world’s best runners and it sends chills down my spine thinking that I am that much closer to my dream. I want to be the best so badly that I will train in any type of weather. In my mind, there is “no excuses”. I feel that I will do well at Nationals as I have proven, in the past, that I run well under pressure. This will be the chance I need to finally get myself noticed by the best schools in the country, and the world. With my coach, Dan Tripp, with me, I have no doubt in my mind that Team Canada is something is doable.  This has been my dream since I started my athletic journey that some just call “running”.

Brad Davis

story:
Hi!  My name is Sean Douglas Leeper.  I am currently a junior studying Biology at Southern Adventist University in Collegedale, Tennessee, with the goal of attending Loma Linda University School of Dentistry and becoming a dentist.  I have created this fundraiser because I’ve been blessed with the opportunity to attend a medical/dental mission trip, during my spring break (and 21st birthday), to a small village roughly 40 kilometers outside of Pucallpa, Peru.  During the trip I will be assisting in a clinic under the leadership of medical and dental professionals and also helping lead a children’s Vacation Bible School in the evenings.  This will be my first mission trip to a different country, and I’m very excited to not only serve the locals, but show them the love of Christ as well.

Here is how you can get involved.  The trip costs $1,800 and if I include the necessary medications and other supplies I need, it is about $2,000.  My goal is to raise $800 by the end of February.  I plan to work, sell some of my possessions, and use savings to cover the rest of the expenses.  The funds I raise will help pay for the cost of my airfare, room and board, and supplies for the trip.  Your donations, no matter the amount will be greatly appreciated by not only myself but the local people as well.  Thank you so much for all your support and taking time to learn about what I will be doing.

“For even the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many.” – Mark 10:45

story:
I would like to share a story with you about a mother that we met for the first time last month (May 30,2015) in Redding in the parking lot of Target with her makeshift car wash. We were told that the car wash was a fundraiser for cancer. Little did we know that one of the 3 people washing the cars had cancer. Annie Burruss was washing cars to help pay for her treatment and medications. She was thin, had dark circle, and she was in a lot of pain. It was heart wrenching to know that we let this woman wash our car in so much pain.
Annie Burruss, 40 years old mother of six, was diagnosed with breast cancer last year. In the first month of breast feeding her baby she thought that she had mastitis (infection of the breast tissue). When the pain continued she decided to have it checked out. She was told that there was a 1% chance that it was cancer. It was cancer and she was advised to stop breast feeding her baby. She had a mastectomy and has been told she has 6 months to 1 year to live. She is struggling to pay for her medications and day to day house hold expenses. She has had to stop working as a hair dresser due to the severe pain. Her hope is to raise enough money to get treatments so she can be able to raise her young family and get through these hard times. Her children’s ages range from 16 years old to the youngest 10 months old.

She is not able to do a full alternative cancer program due to finances. The money raised is going towards pain medications, colonics, light therapy, organic foods and other natural remedies.

story:
The Bakardjiev lab at UCSF is studying how infections during pregnancy affect the placenta and damage the developing baby.

 

Why is this research important?

Infections of the placenta can lead to maternal and fetal illness and death. Preterm labor, for example, is often the result of infection. Every year 15 million neonates are born prematurely. Of these preemies 1.1 million die, and many of the survivors suffer long-term health problems. To improve the health of mothers and children, we need to better understand the mechanisms of placental infections so we can develop strategies to prevent preterm birth and other pregnancy complications.

 

Estimated preterm birth rates by country for the year 2010. (Blencowe et al., 2012)

 

Our work

We are working with the bacterial pathogen Listeria monocytogenes. Infection of the mother during pregnancy with Listeria causes fetal demise, premature labor, or neonatal disease and death. Infection occurs when humans ingest contaminated food. You may have heard of the recent outbreak of listeriosis that was associated with contaminated cantaloupes from Colorado. From August to October 2011, the outbreak reached 28 states. 146 cases of listeriosis were confirmed, and 30 patients died. The outbreak made national headlines as the deadliest outbreak of foodborne illness since 1924.

We have identified the first fetal cells that become infected in the human placenta upon infection with Listeria. We characterized immune mechanisms of fetal placental cells that fight this bacterium. We've also identified bacterial genes that make it possible for Listeria to overcome the immune defenses of the fetal cells of the placenta. We are now starting to investigate how Listeria triggers preterm labor.

               

                       Examples of Listeria (green) in placental tissue and cells.

 

How will your contributions help?

We need your support to collect pilot data for new pathways on how Listeria causes preterm labor. This is critical to convince larger donors that this study can be done! If you want to support basic women’s reproductive health research, or are just fascinated by the mysteries of the placenta, please donate to our campaign! You can also help us by sharing on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn or YouTube.

 

Our team

 

    

We are a small lab at UCSF that aims to change big paradigms! The principal investigator is Dr. Anna Bakardjiev, a pediatric infectious diseases expert who has developed novel approaches to studying infections during pregnancy.  

 

The big picture

Pregnancy is amazing and challenging! Scientifically there is one overarching and unexplained paradox during pregnancy: how is the mother able to carry a genetically distinct fetus within herself? This is a mysetery because the immune system recognizes self versus non-self—that is, something that is part of our body (self) versus something foreign (non-self).

 

Examples of non-self entities are bacteria and parasites, but non-self entities can also be human tissue, as in the case of an organ transplant. People who receive an organ transplant must take medication to suppress their immune system to keep it from rejecting the new organ. The downside is that transplant recipients are more susceptible to infections. Like an organ transplant, a growing fetus is genetically distinct from its mother. Why does the maternal immune system tolerate the fetus? And how can the fetus be protected against infection under such challenging circumstances? These simple questions remain a mystery.

 

For a long time people have proposed that pregnant women are immune-suppressed to avoid immune rejection of the baby. But leaving the most important biological task in life to someone who is immune-suppressed and therefore more susceptible to infections does not seem like a smart strategy! Indeed, more recent scientific evidence suggests that this is really not true. The unique organ that mediates an immunological truce between mother and fetus, and protects the baby from infection, is the placenta.

 

                           

What is the placenta? The placenta is an organ that is only present during pregnancy. It is located in the uterus and made out of maternal and fetal tissues. The two main tasks of the placenta are to nourish and protect the baby, but how the placenta is able to protect the baby both from maternal immune rejection and infection remains an unresolved paradox. 

 

Thank you for your generosity!
story_txt:
The Bakardjiev lab at UCSF is studying how infections during pregnancy affect the placenta and damage the developing baby.
 
Why is this research important?
Infections of the placenta can lead to maternal and fetal illness and death. Preterm labor, for example, is often the result of infection. Every year 15 million neonates are born prematurely. Of these preemies 1.1 million die, and many of the survivors suffer long-term health problems. To improve the health of mothers and children, we need to better understand the mechanisms of placental infections so we can develop strategies to prevent preterm birth and other pregnancy complications.
 

Estimated preterm birth rates by country for the year 2010. (Blencowe et al., 2012)
 
Our work
We are working with the bacterial pathogen Listeria monocytogenes. Infection of the mother during pregnancy with Listeria causes fetal demise, premature labor, or neonatal disease and death. Infection occurs when humans ingest contaminated food. You may have heard of the recent outbreak of listeriosis that was associated with contaminated cantaloupes from Colorado. From August to October 2011, the outbreak reached 28 states. 146 cases of listeriosis were confirmed, and 30 patients died. The outbreak made national headlines as the deadliest outbreak of foodborne illness since 1924.
We have identified the first fetal cells that become infected in the human placenta upon infection with Listeria. We characterized immune mechanisms of fetal placental cells that fight this bacterium. We've also identified bacterial genes that make it possible for Listeria to overcome the immune defenses of the fetal cells of the placenta. We are now starting to investigate how Listeria triggers preterm labor.
               
                       Examples of Listeria (green) in placental tissue and cells.
 
How will your contributions help?
We need your support to collect pilot data for new pathways on how Listeria causes preterm labor. This is critical to convince larger donors that this study can be done! If you want to support basic women’s reproductive health research, or are just fascinated by the mysteries of the placenta, please donate to our campaign! You can also help us by sharing on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn or YouTube.
 
Our team
 
    
We are a small lab at UCSF that aims to change big paradigms! The principal investigator is Dr. Anna Bakardjiev, a pediatric infectious diseases expert who has developed novel approaches to studying infections during pregnancy.  
 
The big picture
Pregnancy is amazing and challenging! Scientifically there is one overarching and unexplained paradox during pregnancy: how is the mother able to carry a genetically distinct fetus within herself? This is a mysetery because the immune system recognizes self versus non-self—that is, something that is part of our body (self) versus something foreign (non-self).
 
Examples of non-self entities are bacteria and parasites, but non-self entities can also be human tissue, as in the case of an organ transplant. People who receive an organ transplant must take medication to suppress their immune system to keep it from rejecting the new organ. The downside is that transplant recipients are more susceptible to infections. Like an organ transplant, a growing fetus is genetically distinct from its mother. Why does the maternal immune system tolerate the fetus? And how can the fetus be protected against infection under such challenging circumstances? These simple questions remain a mystery.
 
For a long time people have proposed that pregnant women are immune-suppressed to avoid immune rejection of the baby. But leaving the most important biological task in life to someone who is immune-suppressed and therefore more susceptible to infections does not seem like a smart strategy! Indeed, more recent scientific evidence suggests that this is really not true. The unique organ that mediates an immunological truce between mother and fetus, and protects the baby from infection, is the placenta.
 
                           
What is the placenta? The placenta is an organ that is only present during pregnancy. It is located in the uterus and made out of maternal and fetal tissues. The two main tasks of the placenta are to nourish and protect the baby, but how the placenta is able to protect the baby both from maternal immune rejection and infection remains an unresolved paradox. 
 
Thank you for your generosity!

story:
HELP SUPPORT CC so she can get her LUNG TRANSPLANT!

I am a nurse who was Blessed to have to opportunity learn and watch CC Wood as a nurse. She is a caring and loving woman. She taught me how to care for newborns in the Nursery and how to be the BEST nurse. 

Six years ago she was diagnosed with stage 4 Sarcodosis and needed to be put on "light duty" which the hospital she worked at did not support. She had to leave a job she loved and has been finding other ways to support her family. From selling Pampered Chef to Thirty-One she is willing to do what it takes to care for the ones she loves. 

Recently her health has really declined which has made it more difficult to work and she was told she may not make it if she even gets a cold. SHE NEEDS NEW LUNGS!

She goes to Mayo in JAX and if she can get $40,000, it will cover her portion of the Lung Transplant. She will also need to remain near Mayo for 3 months to recover. This will include someone(mainly her husband) to care for her and very frequent doctor visits to make sure the surgery is a success. 

CC helped my dreams come true to be a loving and caring nurse. I would love to return the favor for her and help her to get well. I want her to be able to be there for her family and watch her kids grow up.

When I did this video it really hit me how hard it was for her family. I have been around CC, Max, Annette and her husband Anthony quite a few times but had never talked to the kids or her hubby about the Lung Transplant (the Elephant in the room). When I did this video it broke my heart to see Annette SPEACHLESS and then teary eyed... (she ran off right after I stopped filming). She deserves to have her mom there to hold her. I will do anything I can to make that possible for her.

Anything you can do will help! Please DONATE &/OR SHARE!

HELP CC GET HER LUNG TRANPLANT SO SHE CAN BE THERE FOR HER FAMILY!

story:
I am Carolin, my husband Chase is a c6-c7 quad. paralyzed from the chest down as of age 15 when he was hit by a car walking across a road. He is the best husband and father. It however has been hard going places and he him self has never had the freedom of driving. If we could get a handicap friendly,or better yet possibly with hand controls, it would change our family and open a whole new world to him. Up until now we have had a 95 jeep that I as his wife would pick him up and put him in should we need to go anywhere. This is very hard for us both. Now as of today we have NO CAR because as I was driving down our dirt road we live on a white truck ran me and my daughter off the road and into the ditch killing our poor jeep. Thank god my 8yr old daughter Alyzia and I are OK... but we now more than ever need something.

We need at the least a dependable car that I can easily get my husband in and out of! What would be the be a dream come true is a handicap capable car (something I could drive but also my husband with hand controls) . If we could get a nice used car and get it fitted for him it would change his world.

 

if you cant help with a monetary donation I understand as allot of people are having a hard time right now. but please pass it on spread the news. I am putting this out there with faith in the lord he will show us the way.
