story:
Our Team:  2012 US Men's National Bronze Medalists

John Shuster - 2-time Olympian, 4-time US Men's National Champion

Jeff Isaacson - 2010 Olympian, 2009 US Men's National Champion

Jared Zezel - 2011 US Junior National Champion and All-Star Second 

John Landsteiner - 2011 US Junior National All-Star Skip

Team Background:

The 2012-2013 curling season is nearly upon us, and it proves to be a very important one for Team Shuster. With the 2014 Olympic Trials to take place in December of 2013, this year’s USA Men’s National Championships will not only crown this year’s National Champion, it will also determine the final 2 spots at the Olympic Trials.

Last season, Team Shuster narrowly missed capturing one of the first two Olympic Trials berths by finishing 3rd at the 2012 USA National Championships. Thus, the team looks forward to the upcoming season with lofty goals. Building off that 3rd place finish in our inaugural campaign, we will be traveling across North America looking for the best training and competitive opportunities to better that finish.

Why we need your help:

With John L. and Jared being full-time students, and Jeff and John S. only working part time jobs to leave time for training and travel, competing expenses are difficult to come by.

There are limited resources allocated to elite athletes by USA Curling, however, teams like ours who are not already qualified for the Olympic Trials are forced to bear most of the burden of those competing costs ourselves.  (John L. and Jared each receive a small amount from USA Curling's Project 2018 Program)

Last season, our competing costs, which include entry fees, lodging, and travel, topped $10,000.  This upcoming season, our competing costs will be over $11,000.  With just a few sponsors already onboard, we are looking to raise $7000 more so we can put together a competition schedule that can prepare us to win a National Championship, putting us in the 2014 Olympic Trials.

Where we will be Playing this Season:

Event

Location

Dates

Point Optical Curling Classic

Saskatoon, SK Canada

Sept. 21-24

Manitoba Lotteries Men's Classic

Brandon, MB, Canada

Oct. 5-8

St. Paul Cashpiel

St. Paul, MN

Oct. 12-14

Bernick’s Miller Lite Open

Bemidji, MN

Oct. 26-28

Courtesy Freight Superspiel

Thunder Bay, ON, Canada

Nov. 9-11

Coors Light Cashspiel

Duluth, MN

Nov. 23-25

Curl Mesabi Cashspiel

Eveleth, MN

Dec. 14-16

US Men's Qualifying Round

Hibbing, MN

Jan. 2-6

MCA Bonspiel

Winnipeg, MB, Canada

Jan. 17-21

2013 USA National Championships*

Green Bay, WI

Feb. 9-16

2013 World Curling Championships*

Victoria, BC, Canada

Mar. 30-Apr. 7

*denotes events we must qualify for to attend

Webstreaming:

This upcoming season, Team Shuster will be webstreaming many of our games at www.veetle.com, where you can follow our progress along with the thousands who tuned in at the US National Championships last year.

Thank You:

We would like to thank all of you in advance for your support of our team and our dream!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Eran Lavi. I am the CEO and founder of Discover Medical Devices.

I founded and managed 7 companies (3 in medical devices: EpiSafe developed a solution for patients with epilepsy; PJITAW developed solution for mobile diagnostics and Discover Medical Devices that develops a revolutionary CPAP mask). I have participated in development and invention of 10 patents. 
By Education I am a physicist.

In 2006 I decided to try and solve the non compliant problem of sleep apnea patients (more than 50% of people diagnosed with sleep apnea refuse to receive treatment.)  

I found out that most diagnosed patients with sleep apnea refuse to use current masks despite the fact that it is very dangerous to do so. Untreated severe sleep apnea elevates the chances of stroke (250%), elevates the chances of cardiac attack (>300%), cause fatal car accidents (>700%) and more.

I recruited Dr. David Madjar (my partner) who was a section chief of oral rehabilitation unit in Sheba medical center. Together we invented a unique mask - the SomnuSeal.

The SomnuSeal is the only intra oral mask in the world. It is made of soft silicone and adapts to each user even while he/she moves during the night.

The SomnuSeal has the ability to become the best mask because it uses the existing science of complete dentures (it is known medically that people get used to complete dentures because of a phenomenon called habituation).  We anticipated that a medical device (like our novel CPAP mask) that will be designed correctly from soft material, will also be tolerated well within the oral cavity. 

The SomnuSeal mask is made of a soft self adaptable silicone, is comfortable to many people and in the new design (reduction of its size) we anticipate that it will be very comfortable.

Further more the SomnuSeal is the only mask that requires 50% less air pressure than traditional masks. Cardiologists think that this is much better for the heart - no other mask can do that because of our design and location (inside the oral cavity)

We had 2 successful clinical trials with 70 patients. We proved that the SomnuSeal mask works well, however we learned that a majority of patients wanted a smaller size SomnuSeal mask. Thus we will decrease the current SomnuSeal mask size.

We want the SomnuSeal mask to help millions of sleep apnea patients that refuse to use current traditional masks and help current users of CPAP treatment to sleep better by introducing a smaller, more comfortable, SomnuSeal mask.


What We Need & What You Get

Thus far, we raised  $1.7m and accomplished many things: We successfully developed a revolutionary intra oral mask (the SomnuSeal); developed and applied for 2 patents internationally, conducted 2 successful clinical trials, received CE approval, received Amar approval and won a Frost and Sullivan prize.

We want to raise at least $50,000 from potential users in order to develop a smaller size mask. 
In parallel we will work to raise additional funds. 
Success in Indiegogo campaign will help us raise additional funds much faster.


The Impact

Successful campaign will result in the best mask today (in our opinion and based on current clinical trial results and the science we rely on)

We need your help to prove that there are many sleep apnea patients that are waiting for a better mask.


Risks & Challenges

We know how to reduce mask size because we already done that in the past during the development process. The challenge will be to raise funds by as many people as possible to prove a better mask necessity and demand.

If we raise more than $750,000, we will will also start improving our unique SomnuSeal air vent (make it lighter)


Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out - write in blogs, show to doctors, introduce to potential distributors, spread the news to everyone because the next connection you have may know a patient that needs the mask. Thus we hope that a chain of introductions  will be quickly formed by you, until many patients receive the news of a new type of CPAP mask and will also want to help.

story:
Hello Everyone!

Our good friend Riki needs your help!

The Story:

On Tuesday July 22nd our good friend Riki was hanging out with Pedro, our friend from Lotus, at a bar. They were chilling out after working hard at the restaurant and having a good time when they left their drinks at the bar to go to the bathroom. Well that happens to be the last thing Riki remembers for the night up until he woke up screaming and crying in pain.

Anyway, Riki and Pedro came back and apparently drank a little more at the bar and went to a nearby park to have a few more beers (according to Pedro). Now Riki isn't one to drink till he's smashed drunk but granted he may have been drugged.

While at the park Riki, Pedro and Pedro's girlfriend were hanging out enjoying some more beer and then Pedro and his girlfriend went to the bathroom. Upon returning they found poor Riki on the floor crying, screaming and throwing up from the pain. He was then promptly taken to the emergency room where they found out his knee was broken. After going to the clinic the next day Riki found out he needs immediate surgery!

Riki and Pedro dressing up for Halloween!

Why he needs us:

Riki is a rich man, well rich in love and compassion. Unfortunately, like many of us he is not the richest in money. But that's ok! Because he has wonderful people like you who are willing to donate even the smallest amount to help him out. The money you contribute will go towards his knee surgery and hopefully also to his rehabilitation.

Because of his injury Riki is unable to work as a server (a job he kicks ass at!), the pain is preventing him from concentrating on his studies and of course there is the obvious: He can't leave the house because he lives on the second floor with no elevator!!

Riki chillin with Robin and Marco at Lotus where they work together.


Why he deserves our help:

We might be biased but we think Riki is an awesome dude! He puts his all into everything he does including his job, his education and his relationships which is why it would be worthwhile for you to help this wonderful friend get back on his feet.

Personally when I (Ben) worked with him at Lotus he would always treat me well. As a runner/busser I wasn't always very much respected but Riki got me. He would always remember to say thank you and even kick in some extra tip to show how much he appreciated all the work I was doing.

Moreover Riki is a dedicated server at Lotus who always puts the customer first. He takes orders and delivers food at lightning speed all while making the customer happy.

Riki is a hard working student earning his BFA in writing and directing at the Academy of Arts University San Francisco. He hopes to work in the entertainment industry and bring his amazing vision to life. But he's multi-talented! He also studies programming, music, the fine art of bartending and much more!

Whenever I have problems he always listens and relates to what I say. Riki is a true friend that deserves a little help from awesome people like you!

With this money Riki can fix his knee and get better which is just what he needs to get back to making people happy!

From left to right: Pedro, Desmond, ME (Ben), and Riki. We're all happy hanging out together after working hard at Lotus.

What you can do:

We know that money is tight these days what with the economy the way it is and all. But the truth is there is strength in numbers. This means that even if you can't donate a whole lot it's ok! The important thing is that you follow these two principles:

1. Donate what you think you can. Even a dollar gets Riki closer to recovery.

2. Even if you can't donate (or you have) remember to share this with others in the hope that fellow generous souls will contribute to this noble cause.

Riki needs us! So whatever you can contribute will help him a great deal! Always remember that we're sending out much love to anyone who lends a helping hand whether it's through donating or just spreading the word to help this amazing friend!


Thanks! Much Love!

Ben and Ivy

Riki is a true friend that deserves a little help from awesome people like you!With this money Riki can fix his knee and get better which is just what he needs to get back to making people happy!From left to right: Pedro, Desmond, ME (Ben), and Riki. We're all happy hanging out together after working hard at Lotus.What you can do:We know that money is tight these days what with the economy the way it is and all. But the truth is there is strength in numbers. This means that even if you can't donate a whole lot it's ok! The important thing is that you follow these two principles:1. Donate what you think you can. Even a dollar gets Riki closer to recovery.2. Even if you can't donate (or you have) remember to share this with others in the hope that fellow generous souls will contribute to this noble cause.Riki needs us! So whatever you can contribute will help him a great deal! Always remember that we're sending out much love to anyone who lends a helping hand whether it's through donating or just spreading the word to help this amazing friend!Thanks! Much Love!Ben and Ivy

story:
Kicking Cancer In The Teeth!

It's time to throw some punches and keep it real. My name is Lisbeth Russell aka Black Betty, I am a freelance illustrator, nerd and food maniac from Scandinavia. I have been living in the dusty West of Australia since 2005, and through my travels, sticking my dirty toes in the ganges in India to spotting howler monkeys in The Amazon Rainforest, I have met some pretty fine people out there that have changed my perception on life, challenged my ideas and just generally made me feel a whole lot of love. I am alive and I am grateful for the life I have lived so far, and all the years to come. I have plans for the future. I want to go back to India and work with children. I also want to check out Canada with my amazing boyfriend. I want to help others. I also have plans to eat more french toast. One day I might even want a family. I have dreams. Everyone deserves to live a happy and fulfilled life, following the dreams that are true to them. In the scheme of things, if one person is happy and full of love, it spreads leaps and bounds and it affects other people, even animals and our environment. You may have met complete strangers who have passed you on the street smiling, and you may have wondered 'gurh, do I have porridge in my beard again?', but no, no sweet leftover breakfast dangling. They were just smiling. And some days, their smile makes you smile too, even when it feels awkward. But that ain't too bad. At least you are smiling. Through that smile, you may make someone else's day better, you may flick a switch in someone else just through your own determination to be joyful. 

  Enough babble, I think you get the idea. My two buddies, Kylie Farrell and Brad O'Brien both have cancer. 

  Kylie is an amazing chef with an unstoppable drive when it comes to her friends and family. She's honest, true and incredibly giving, even now going through this rough time, Kylie has MORE than enough to give to her loved ones. Incredible. Kylie has already had to deal with this cancer culprit once before, so NOW is the time to knock the bugger on the head. Kylie inspires me to speak up and be the strong woman I aspire to be with sass and determination! All the love to this powerful Goddess!

  My dear friend Brad is another kettle of fish, yet they both share the experience of having this illness once before in their life. Brad is like a brother to me. He is larger than life, in so many ways. I am amazed to witness the lifestyle changes he has been through these last two months. His energy blows me away and leaves me inspired to keep pursuing eating organics, living healthy and making sure I have more than enough awesome vibes to share around. I love you man.

  Kylie and Brad are both young, early 30's.They both have dreams and plans. Without them in my life, I wouldn't be who I am today. It's a massive journey.. I dont think I have talked so much about enemas in my entire life! but seriously though, even in Australia, different treatments, organic fruit and veggies, MSM, enemas, medicine, consultations and so forth, all cost money. So.. all my love heading their way, along with my nifty painting skills, using gouache for the first time, I want to boost these two amazing people with money which they can put towards whatever they feel is important for them to help heal, so they can get back on track. 

I am donating two paintings and a shitload of vinyl stickers!

My paintings are 100% original and inspired by my journey into the Amazon, when I pursued my own truth and healing. There are two individual pieces up for grabs!

1st painting: Amazon Kayapo Tribe child, gouache on canvas, purple with dark blue face paint. 36CMX25CM. 

2nd painting: Amazon Kayapo Tribe child, gouache on canvas, pale green with purple and red face paint. 30CMX24CM.  

Small donations are awesome too, anything helps! everyone who donates $10.00 and over, gets a FREE set of vinyl stickers with my designs! 

ALL funds will be split between Brad and Kylie to go towards whatever they need right now. 

When the deadline for the campaign is hit, I will make the winners of the paintings official on my website www.jazzombie.com and on the facebook event page https://www.facebook.com/events/290222654487671/!

Through your donation, you remember, honour and love everyone who has been through hardship. We are one.

This is real guys. Life is what it is, a bittersweet symphony. Regardless of the situations we have been through individually, we can all relate to hardship. We can all make a difference. We can change everything.

Other ways you can help..

Some of you beautiful people aren't able to donate. For you I ask, please spread the word. This message is only full of love. If anything, it may inspire others. I aim to inspire. By using the Indigogo share tools, you personally spread the word and can make a massive difference to the amount of money that will be donated. Money is where it's at. Like I said, I am keeping it real.

Love to all of you, have an amazing journey wherever you are in the world. With all my sincere gratitude, bless you all.

story:
Hi guys,

My name is Cristian Mihai. Some of you may know me from my blog, some by reading my stories and books, and others through various websites I administered along the years.

Ever since I was a boy I had trouble with my teeth. A calcium deficiency. Along the years the situation has progressed from sensitive teeth to, well, a really bad situation.

The last two weeks have been terrible. My right ear began to hurt. Then the right side of my jaw. And painkillers wouldn't do much good. I struggled. Pain followed me everywhere, prevented me from sleeping...

I went to see a dentist. She prescribed antibiotics and painkillers… it did the trick. Apparently, to blame for all this is an infected tooth… well, the infection spread out to other teeth.

I went and had an X-Ray.

The treatment costs a lot more than I can afford to pay at the time: approximately $1100. It is an urgent matter.

I just want for things to be okay. I want to be able to sleep and eat, which is something we all take for granted. It’s not extraordinary or fascinating. Simple acts, things we do all our lives.

story:
The idea:


Romania has a very very high potential for gliding. The weather situation is very good and the landscape profile is perfect for long distance flights in thermals and wave. The region is comparable to areas like Spain, South Africa or Australia and has the same potential. The reason why nobody has explored it yet is the poor infrasturcture with nearly no performance gliders, tug's and knowledge.

Gliding in Romania is well represented by the national aeroclub in some places over the country. They make an excellent basic training and they manage to get a lot of young people start flying, they organise competitions and advanced training for gliding. But to spread the faszination of gliding more and more over the country and to attract also some foreign pilots to enjoy gliding in Romania,  more and more private airclub's were set up. Most of them are using the winch to start their flights, but to perform big distance flights, flying in the waves or for aerobatics, a tow plane would be needed.

This is the reason why we want to buy a tug which we can use anywhere it's needed. At the moment we are looking foreward to buy a Morane Rallye 180, just because it is cheap, easy to fly and able to stay outside. But all kind of other offers to keep an airplane for towing or a performance glider here would be also very welcome. 

Having a dedicated plane for towing would be a milestone in the gliding infrastructure in Romania and a big step to explore this "East European Gliding Paradise"!


But:

For this first small investment we need your support! 


We would be very delighted if you can help us making our project become true and if we will see us one day for gliding in Romania.


Thank you very much!

story:
The recent resurgence of bicycles, tricycles, fixies, BMX bikes and all other two wheeled push bikes and custom rides has changed the way many of us get around. More of us are riding to work rather than taking the bus or train - it's more fun, it's healthy and it's a cost effective means of transport. But on the down side...the increase in bicycles on the road has also led to an increase in bicycle accidents. 

From 2011 to 2012 in the UK, there was a 10% increase in cycling fatalities, and a 4% rise in serious injuries. 


In response we have developed CYCLE GUARDIAN, the first accident prevention device for cyclists. 

What does it do..? 

Using some very cool technology, CYCLE GUARDIAN measures the speed and proximity of surrounding vehicles. If a moving vehicle comes too close to the cyclist, an audible alarm and high-power LED light is set off - alerting both the cyclist and the driver of the vehicle. 

You can customise your device too! By choosing your own alert sound. 

How does it work..? 

CYCLE GUARDIAN attaches to your seat post and uses a combination of ultrasonic motion detection and photo-electric distance measuring technologies to take continuous measurements of the speed and proximity of surrounding objects. By combining these readings, CYCLE GUARDIAN is able to tell the difference between a fast-moving car and a stationary object such as a tree or fence.  




Who are we..? 

We are a passionate team of inventors based in the UK...we are also avid and daily cyclists! We came up with the idea for CYCLE GUARDIAN after a car got a bit too close one too many times...

Where is your money going..?

We are raising £30k to build our prototype and bring CYCLE GUARDIAN to the market.

The money will be going to specialist engineers and designers to finalise the design of the device and build a prototype. We already have a patent for the technology in place, and an initial design. If we can raise the funds we will have the finished product ready by the end of the year! 

Help us bring CYCLE GUARDIAN to the cyclists around the world and start preventing accidents and saving lives.

Thanks for checking out our campaign! 

- The team at CYCLE GUARDIAN -

story:
Thanks for Being Part of Our Endeavor!

Designs for the World LLC creates and manufactures humanitarian and medical products for people in developing nations, in disaster areas, and in war zones.  We use our experience in engineering, biology, and project management to innovate for the 5.8 billion people who do not live in industrialized nations.  We invite you to learn about our lead innovation for the underserved 83% of humanity.

Infant Mortality in the Developing World

  • Of the 4 million babies who die each year, 99% are born in developing nations.
  • 1.8 million of these infants who are born premature and at-risk perish from hypothermia.  More than 3 of the newest residents of the Earth die every minute.
  • Access to working incubators would improve the survival of newborns.

The Tikü™ Incubator

  • The Tikü™ works without electricity, unlike conventional incubators that often fail in regions without reliable electrical power.
  • The Tikü™ is portable, simple-to-use, requires virtually no maintenance, and is available to mothers in remote locations.
  • The Tikü™ costs a fraction of the price of conventional incubators.
  • The Tikü™ helps to isolate baby from the insect hosts of malaria, dengue fever, encephalitis, sleeping sickness, and leishmaniasis.

How You Can Help Us Get the Tikü™ to Babies Who Need It

  • Your support will enable us to fabricate several incubators for evaluation.
  • After testing by biomedical technologists at St. Petersburg College, the incubators will be assessed for approval of manufacturing and quality by the FDA and the ISO.
  • These incubators will then be demonstrated to caregivers in Haiti and gifted to local humanitarian agencies.
  • We may then respond to the interest in procuring the incubators by governmental, humanitarian, and religious organizations.

Our Thanks for Your Help

  • For those of you who wish to contribute, we shall pay forward 7% of your donations to the Children’s Dream Fund, which is a charitable organization that has been helping make the dreams come true for children with life-threatening illnesses for over three decades.
  • Your gift will bring happiness to kids who are fighting the pain and uncertainty of chronic illness, in addition to helping us provide the gift of life to babies with the Tikü™.
  • If you are unable to contribute, please share news of our campaign with your friends and families by way of email and social media.  Your outreach through Facebook, Twitter, Google+, LinkedIn, Instagram, and other media will help us to spread our message about the Tikü™.  Take advantage of the sharing tools of Indiegogo.  PLEASE SHARE OFTEN and help us to reach our goal!

The Gift of Children

  • Virtually every family has been touched by the birth of a premature or at-risk baby who has struggled for life from the moment of entry into the world.
  • Fortunately, most of us have been blessed by having access to proper medical care that has enabled us to start our lives and later to have families of our own.
  • Your help will allow us to provide caregivers with a new and versatile incubator that will give a chance for life to many babies in the developing world.
  • We appreciate your generosity...but mostly

The Mothers Thank You All!


Other Ways You Can Help!
If you like our project but you can't make a monetary contribution, please consider sharing it with your friends and family using the share buttons under the video. This will help us to spread the word.  Thank you.

You Will Enjoy Reading the Updates
We encourage you to review the updates to the campaign.  You will gain a greater appreciation for the features and operation of the Tikü incubator.  You will also learn more about the people, who will benefit from our innovation.  Their lives have challenges that are unique to their cultures.  We are striving to enable them to improve the quality of their lives and provide a better future for their children. 


Visit Us on the Web

story:
Sayed is the victim of coward's punch. He was king hit on the streets of Mt Isa in an unprovoked attack and fell backward and hit hit head on the concrete. (http://www.northweststar.com.au/story/2169393/witness-sees-unprovoked-late-night-assault-on-man/ )
This has had a profound effect on his life. According to his doctor he is suffering "Major depression with anxiety, Post Traumatic Stress Disorder and Post Concussion syndrome" which has meant he has had to resign from his job as a rubber technician because "it was no longer safe for him to use his tools of trade and because of his cognitive deficit".

Unfortunately Sayed needed that job to fund his mother's healthcare.  Sayed's mother, who is a refugee living in Pakistan, has a meningioma in the brain that urgently needs to be removed. Not operating, according to her doctor, would be a "danger for her survival". This operation, along with other medical and hospital charges, will cost $6000.

Sayed should eventually get some victims's compensation money * but this will be too late to fund his mother's operation. 

There are a number of ways you can help Sayed.

  • Donate to the fund
  • Offer Sayed a loan so he can fund his operation and repay you when he receives his compensation.
  • Circulate this appeal throughout your networks.
Documents verifying Sayed's plight are available on request. Contact Mark at mgillespie3@gmail.com
* Update: Since this campaign was first initiated and the video above was made Sayed has received a significant interim payment from victim's compensation but not enough to cover all medical costs so we still need to continue with our fundraising.

story:
"Nobody can do everything, but everyone can do something" - unknown

  • We, the Virtual Nook Team is a group of young people with a heart for helping our community in any way that we can through various programs like feeding program, back-to-school projects and our recent program, the "medical mission".
  • We focus our mission in helping our community. We live in a island often visited by typhoons, thus making our community vulnerable to devastation caused by it; losing their houses and means of living.
  • We started this last 2009. Our first-ever project is community feeding program which targeted around 100 malnourished kids in a far-flung area in our island.
  • We used to get our funding from our personal pockets, we pool our extra resources to raise an amount for a certain project. Recently some good friends started sharing an amount for our upcoming missions, thanks to their good heart, but the demands and requests for Medical missions from other areas flooded our inboxes making our team even more eager to raise an amount to suffice our mission.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We needed cash to buy medicines particularly multivitamins for malnourished kids and the elderly.
  • In every medical mission, we also do feeding program where the patients are served with nutritious meals or light snacks while waiting for their turn.
  • We would really appreciate any amount that you would give :) , we can not give anything in return except our sincere "Thank you" note and prayers to God to bless your kind heart for helping us :) 

Other ways you can help

Please share this on your Facebook Wall or through email so that your friends will know about this
story_txt:
"Nobody can do everything, but everyone can do something" - unknown 
We, the Virtual Nook Team is a group of young people with a heart for helping our community in any way that we can through various programs like feeding program, back-to-school projects and our recent program, the "medical mission".
We focus our mission in helping our community. We live in a island often visited by typhoons, thus making our community vulnerable to devastation caused by it; losing their houses and means of living.
We started this last 2009. Our first-ever project is community feeding program which targeted around 100 malnourished kids in a far-flung area in our island.
We used to get our funding from our personal pockets, we pool our extra resources to raise an amount for a certain project. Recently some good friends started sharing an amount for our upcoming missions, thanks to their good heart, but the demands and requests for Medical missions from other areas flooded our inboxes making our team even more eager to raise an amount to suffice our mission.


  What We Need & What You Get 
We needed cash to buy medicines particularly multivitamins for malnourished kids and the elderly.
In every medical mission, we also do feeding program where the patients are served with nutritious meals or light snacks while waiting for their turn.
We would really appreciate any amount that you would give :) , we can not give anything in return except our sincere "Thank you" note and prayers to God to bless your kind heart for helping us :)  
  Other ways you can help
Please share this on your Facebook Wall or through email so that your friends will know about this

story:
It started when I was a kid

When I was 10 years old boy on my body I found first little red spot... I thinked - its nothink... Its disappear. But it was not true .... 

Year after year on my body appeared more spots ... Today I cant to go swimming pool. I cant to show my body on public .... In this disease there is no cure ...

I shy to take photo of my face .... 

Only one way how to have clear body is biological cure. But the insurance company will not pay. Because its so expencive cure.

Injection for one month cost 1200 USD. Its Humira - biological injection. For one year of clear body I must pay 14400 USD. But I have not money for this expencive cure.

This can by way for my normal life. Without shy for my illness.

Please for help with this disease and take me a chance to have cleare body for one year.

Im 30 years old and 10 years I have spots like on photo .... 


I thank very much all contributors who want to contribute

story:
i am ruth auta, i want to raise funds for health reasons,as my weight is getting out of control and is causing me and my family great concern. i need funds to help me loose weight and keep it off,i need to have a gastric band fitted to control the amount of food i can consume. there is diabetes in my family and i am in a high risk of getting it. if it does not happen i will keep gaining weight, which will lead to heart problems, i already have foot and walking problems which restricts my ability to work and do any vigorous exercise, i could get diabetes,stroke,high blood pressure, i already get tightness of the chest sometimes. i am doing this for myself and for my family, as an immediate member of my family already has diabetes. and lots of other members of my family and friends have it. the funds will make my life and theirs better and easier. i am technically classified as obese at the moment.it is very important that i get the funds, please assist me, my family and friends to regain our health. when i reach my goal i will be able to work full time, start a business,pursue a modelling career,help other people who are struggling with their weight, i cannot help others at the moment unless i sort myself out.

i will greatly appreciate your help.

Thank you

story:
Carol has a zeal for preparing healthy foods in a wholesome manner. In fact, she considers healthy food production to be a low-rated yet vitally important job. She is a big believer in ‘the leaves being provided for the healing of the nations.’ A great concern of hers is the abundance of food and medicine being made available for human consumption that is man-manipulated to our detriment.

Where do you eat out when you want to eat an organic, home-cooked meal that is healthy and healing for your body and soul? My plan is for Carol’s Organic Kitchen to provide the answer to this question. My kitchen will be a service for the people in the community providing organically prepared food with a home-cooked style, prepared in a healthy manner, including the use of non-hazardous cleaners in the food prep /clean-up process with-in a comfortable and natural-looking dining area, complete with live plants and herbs combined with customers always being greeted with a warm smile.

As the prospective owner, Carol is seeking $500,000 for the purpose of purchasing a building (including any remodeling), purchasing of food prep equipment, dishes, food, getting everything up to code and hiring workers. Carol will have full support from her family's Heating, AC, & Appliance Repair Business in the providing of low cost appliances, repairs, and remodeling. Food will be locally sourced from my own gardens and also from Azure Standard Organic Farms.

You may know Carol as she has worked as a Substitute Teacher at the Quad Cities Community Schools  for many years. You may not know that she is also a tireless home cook and a big natural and simple living advocate. She enjoys people and is excited about providing the community with a very nutritious and enjoyable eating experience!

story:
I have been prepairing for this trip for two years: worked at my physical form, climbed Elbrus (5642 m) and had a night almost on its top, persuaded the leader of the trip that the girl like me will endure all altitudinal hardships and heavy backpacks' weight.

But today because of the ecomical situation and high currency rate in Ukraine (we need dollars to exchange in Tajikistan) my salary does not effort me to buy the necessary sum. That is why I am forced to ask for help.

The raised money I plan to spend on:

- transfer to the hiking district and back

- necessary permissions

- food for 39 hiking days

- return ticket if i have something left :-)

I really hope that the Universe and people in it will be kind to me and my aspiration will come true. 

In addition this trip if successful will become the final material for a book, a book about mountains.

To learn more about me you can on FB or at my personal blog.


 О возможности пойти в поход на Памир я узнала еще два года назад, правда единственной загвоздкой было то, что руководитель был против девочек в походе. Пришлось готовится, на Эльбрус сходить, почти переночевать там, сделать операцию по смене пола (шучу :-) ) - и вот оно, чудо! Я - в команде!

Правда, сейчас, из-за запредельного курса доллара и потери депозита, мечта как-то грозит отодвинуться. Билет в Душанбе уже есть, группа готовится, а на походные траты в самом Таджикистане моей зарплаты, к сожалению, не хватает.

Поэтому и пришлось просить помощи у общественности. 

Собранные средства планирую потратить на:

- переезд к месту старта похода и обратно;

- пропуск в пограничную зону и регистрация;

- закупка продуктов и топлива;

- если что-то останется - на обратный билет :-)

Не могу представить своей жизни без Гор и поэтому очень надеюсь, что Вселенная и люди в ней будут ко мне благосклонны и помогут осуществлению заветной мечты.

А еще, при удачном осуществлении, этот поход станет финальным материалом для написания книги, книги о горах и людях в них.

story:
Hi.  I am Kathy's cousin.  The following is her story in her own words...

My name is Kathy Abbott and I am a 29 year old mother of three beautiful children and wife to my amazing husband.  At the age of five I was diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes.  My family and I managed my condition as best we could but when I was eight it was found that my diabetes had triggered epilepsy as well.  Thankfully, as I grew older, my medication and hormones changed and I grew out of the epilepsy at around thirteen.

Meanwhile, from the time of my diagnosis, my life has been a constant shuffle of doctors, specialist appointments, highs and lows (especially in regards to my sugar levels) and learning the signs and triggers of hyper and hypo glycemic episodes (fits) which can lead to memory loss at one end of the scale and coma/death at the other.

Because of my disease no part of my life was ever normal.  My mother was so concerned about my blood sugar levels it affected my ability to participate in school sports or have sleep-overs with friends.  I remember going to birthday parties and watching all the other kids eat lollies and race around like kids should, but I was just a bystander.  In my mid-teens, my ability or inability to have children was discussed.  I was told that it would be extremely hard for me to have or conceive children as it could lead to sporadic blood sugar levels and miscarriage.

When I was 19 I met Chris, my now husband, through mutual friends.  I had never known anybody so intent on knowing as much as possible about my condition.  While his workmates would take their Playboy magazines to read on their lunch breaks, Chris would read up on medical books, leaflets and anything else he could source to help me manage my illness.  His support, understanding and desire to get me as healthy as possible and keep me there is what enabled us to conceive our first baby at the age of 21.

We were in such a state of disbelief that we did several tests and even after the doctors confirmed it, we found it hard to believe.  Sadly, due to my unstable sugar levels, we miscarried in the first trimester. I can't put into words how that felt.  I felt like such a failure; we'd done our very best, but our very best brought us heartache like we'd never known.  Throughout all the appointments, tests, scripts, happiness and sadness, Chris was my rock and always there for me.  I kind of waited for him to just get tired of it all and leave but he never did.

When we married in 2006, I didn't realise I was pregnant again.  I found out just before we suffered yet another loss.  After the third miscarriage, the emotional pain had taken its toll.  I couldn't handle any more disappointment and grief.  I decided the doctors were right - it was going to be next to impossible for us to have children and I was done.

During the following months a specialist in Mackay prescribed me a new and better insulin and referred me to an opthamologist (a diabetic eye care specialist).  There I was diagnosed with diabetic retinopathy, a condition that damages the blood vessels inside the retina leading to vision loss and blindness.  The procedure to correct this would prove to be both painful and costly.

We took several trips from Mackay to Brisbane for laser eye surgery and a victrectomy (surgery to remove vitreous humor from the eye).  It took months of pain and eyecare. I was completely reliant on Chris to get me to doctors' appointments as I couldn't drive.  Even getting around the house was difficult and I needed help with just about everything.  Still, Chris was there for me.

While all this was going on, I fell pregnant yet again.  I didn't allow myself to get excited this time as I was certain it would end the same way as before. However, after four months, I started to believe that maybe the newly prescribed insulin was keeping my blood sugar levels in check and this pregnancy was going to last!  We had finally made it this far!  We made the decision to move back to Dalby to be closer to family and to the medical treatment I was recieving in Brisbane.

At 28 weeks, my health began to waiver.  My blood pressure went through the roof, so high that it alone should have killed me.  As I recall, it was 240/160!  The staff at Toowoomba Hospital tried for two days to stabilise my pre-eclemspia to no avail.  I was transferred to the Mater Hospital in Brisbane where they informed me upon arrival and observation that at only 28 weeks and five days gestation our baby was to be born via emergency cesarean.  I was terrified.  How could he make it?  How could he possibly survive?

When Noah was born on the 8th of October 2009, he was immediately rushed to the Special Care Unit and attached to the various machines that would give him his only chance of survival.  I was taken to the Intensive Care Unit where I was stabilised for two weeks. All I had was a photograph of my baby until I was well enough to be wheeled down to see my tiny boy.  When I look back on the day it finally happened, I feel so overwhelmed.  I was elated, but because of my eye surgeries, I could barely see him.  It didn't matter though because he was alive!  All 1.2 kilos of him, fighting to survive.

Over the next three months, Noah stayed in the special care unit and day by day, grew stronger. Chris and I learned how to care for our premature baby who still relied on oxygen and a nasal tube for feeding.  Christmas of that year, I got the most amazing gift of all - we got to bring our miracle home.  Although he still required oxygen and suffered chronic lung disease, he was home...with us.

Noah remained on oxygen for the first seven months of his life.  Chris and I had to carry the oxygen tanks everywhere we went until his lungs grew strong enough. Our little boy had bettered the odds!  Throughout all the doctors, peadiatricians, physiotherapists and sleep studies appointments he had along the way, Noah was diagnosed with spastic diplegia, a type of cerebral palsy that mainly affects the mobility of the lower half of his body.  Months of physiotherapy was required and when Noah started walking despite the odds stacked against him, I was so proud!  I have drawn all of my strength and inspiration from watching my boy defy the doctors' predictions.

Shortly after Noah's first birthday we received one hell of a shock when we discovered we were expecting...TWINS!  I was already considered high risk due to my own health and previous complications during pregnancy and birth and now I was carrying twins, doubling the load on my body.  Despite all these factors I remained stable until I reached 24 weeks.  Again I was diagnosed with pre-eclampsia and admitted to the Brisbane Mater Hospital where they are equipped to handle premature twins if I went into early labour.  Chris, Noah and I stay at the Ronald McDonald house until I went into labour at 31 weeks.  Unable to stop the labour, another emergency cesarean was performed.

During the surgery, I lost over two litres of blood, flat-lined, was resuscitated and required a blood transfusion.  But in between all the drama, I actually got to hold Phoebe, one of my twin girls.  It was an experience I had missed out on two out of three times. Emily was rushed to the neonatal incubator.  I managed to recover in the Intensive Care Unit and my baby girls, although premature, were in good health.  However, throughout my pregnancy my kidney function began to deteriorate.

I handled life okay for the first few months, but eventually diabetes, high blood pressure, newborn twins, a child with cerebral palsy and waning kidney function became too much for me and I realised I needed help.  Once again, Chris was there for me.  Still.  He stopped working and stayed home to help me manage the family and my health.  A few months later, a career opportunity arose for Chris back near Mackay so we packed up again and headed north.

We settled into our new life and home in Mackay and Chris was doing well in his job.  The only downfall was he had to travel three and a half hours to work and worked ten days away at a time.  So I was left in a new town without a vehicle, three children under three, managing Noah's CP, the twins' teething and of course, my own health.  I struggled for a year and a half before we decided a move to Moranbah, nearer to where Chris worked would make life easier.  Not only was it cheaper living, it also meant Chris could come home every day and be home sooner if I needed him urgently.

It was a good decision as I had begun having dizzy spells from diminishing iron levels.  Follow-up tests were done and I was sent to a renal specialist.  Further testing showed my kidney function was as low as 17%.  When I was given this news it felt like something out of the movies.  Everything went quiet.  I could see the doctor speaking, the kids playing on the office floor, Chris looking at me and holding my hand, but there was no sound.  There was just this raw fear and uncertainty.   And millions of questions.  I remember being so, so scared.

I was informed that while my kidney function would continue to drop, I would have to wait until it dropped to 10% before I could start dialysis.  By the time it got that low I was basically bedridden.  It actually turned out to be at 6% before I had my first procedure for hemodialysis, which involved having a catheter inserted into my neck, across my lungs and resting on my heart to clean and filter my blood.

The next day I had to go under anaesthesia to have the peritoneal dialysis catheter operation.  What was meant to be a routine day operation ended with me spending a week in hospital from a bleeding complication.  For two and a half days I bled out.  The staff tried to apply (excruciating!) pressure to stem the blood flow, otherwise another operation would've been necessary.  I was so anaemic that I needed an iron infusion before going home.

PD (peritoneal dialysis) was my preferred method of treatment for renal failure as I had more freedom with my diet and busy lifestyle and I could do it anywhere as long as it was sterile. A PET test also confirmed it as the best method for me as the membrane where the fluid sits likes to be wet. Renal failure occurs when the kidneys can no longer adequately filter waste products from the blood.  But the catheter for PD had to be in place for six weeks before it could be used.  Meanwhile, it was necessary for me to continue to endure HD (hemodialysis) because the Home Renal Unit in Mackay wasn't going to open until after the new year and I was so ill that I couldn't go without treatment any longer.

The HD meant Chris and I had to drive into Mackay - a three hour drive, have dialysis (five hours) then turn around and drive the three hours home again.  We did this every two days for three months.  The sheer expense of it all was crippling.  I also had a reaction to the HD;  while my blood was being filtered by the machine, my blood pressure would skyrocket, resulting in a migraine-like headache.  Once the HD was done and I emptied my bladder, my blood pressure would return to normal.  There was nothing to be done about it, it was just an individual reaction my body had to the treatment.

Finally the week long training for managing my own PD came.  This was done in Mackay so we drove the kids up to Townsville to meet with family who took them to stay in Cairns, while Chris and I learnt everything about doing PD at home.  The PD I do involves four bag exchanges a day, 4-6 hours apart.  The last dwell is at around 11 pm and stays in my stomach until around 8.30 am.  I have had to do this every day for the last seven months no matter how shitty I feel or what else is going on.

Two weeks into my home PD, I received a call from my transplant co-ordinator/surgeon at the Westmead Hospital in Sydney. They wanted to see me to assess the possibility of a dual kidney and pancreas transplant!  I had been working towards this appointment for the past couple of months.  Many blood tests, scans, x-rays and reports from all of my specialists were needed to prove that I was a good candidate for transplant surgery.

For a long time I'd been drawing strength from the prospect of this appointment but in the days leading up to this, a dear friend of mine who also suffered from Type 1 diabetes slipped into a coma for the last time after a long and difficult battle.  He was the only person I could talk to and know that he truly understood what I was going through as he had dealt with and suffered through it all already.  When he passed, I felt guilty as I was going through the motions of receiving organs that could've saved his life.  I felt so torn because on one hand, I wanted to go and show my respects but on the other I felt the best way to honour him was to attend the appointment.  To have a chance at a normal life.  I'm sure that's what he would have wanted.

So I met with one of the surgeons and finalised all the paperwork.  They checked me inside and out and decided I was a suitable candidate for the transplant.  Words cannot describe how that felt.  I was on the transplant list!  I felt a mixture of excitement, fear and hope.  Hope for a brighter, healthier, more normal future for me and my family.  For the next three months everything went well.  I attended regular renal specialist and endocrinologist appointments with no problems, so we decided to treat the kids to a holiday in Cairns. It was wonderful!

The night before we headed home, I woke in the night with pains in my chest and had trouble breathing.  I dealt with it all night, thinking it was a bad case of heartburn but by morning it became unbearable and an ambulance was called.  My blood pressure was something like 240/160.  A whirlwind of scans followed.  My enzyme levels were checked and showed the presence of troponin, which meant I had in fact, suffered and survived a heart attack!

They watched my levels for a few days and sent me for a cardiogram, then an angiogram.  They attempted the first angiogram in my wrist but all my veins were too flimsy so they had to try again through my groin.  A narrowing of my circumflex artery was discovered and I was told I would need a stint put in my heart. This meant I would be removed from the active transplant list.  My glimmer of hope was gone.  I was devastated at being removed from the waiting list.

Initially, it was to be for twelve months but after speaking with my transplant team in Sydney and an adjustment in medication, it was changed to six months.  I continued with the medication following the stint operation and a stress test would then determine if I would then go back on the active transplant list.

A few weeks later I had to be flown out of Moranbah to Mackay where I was diagnosed with, and treated for pericarditis (fluid around the heart).  Yet another week was spent in hospital and yet again, Chris was there for me like he'd always been.  He and the kids spent hours driving back and forth to the hospital to be with me.  In the following weeks I had an angina attack and also lost my paternal grandmother, which was a whole other kind of pain.

On returning home from my grandmother's funeral down south, I was diagnosed with an extreme case of pneumonia and a collapsed lung with a remarkable amount of fluid around it.  To make it worse, I had a reaction to the pain medication and was unable to keep down any food or water.  The nausea was so terrible I couldn't even stomach smells or movement.  I lost eight kilograms in under a week! The opiate medication they then put me on virtually put me in a vegetative state but the nausea remained.  My only option was to go without the pain relief and just deal with the pain.

To remove the fluid from my lung, a tube had to be inserted through my back and allowed to drain out.  This process took two days.  Then x-rays were taken to ensure the lung had recovered sufficiently and no more fluid had accumulated. I was in hospital for eleven days before I happily went home.  While a bad cough remained, I eased back into routine and was feeling okay for the first time in a while.  But after two weeks, I felt the familiar swooshing sensation in my chest and knew I'd have to return to hospital...again.

understanding and desire to get me as healthy as possible and keep me there is what enabled us to conceive our first baby at the age of 21.We were in such a state of disbelief that we did several tests and even after the doctors confirmed it, we found it hard to believe.  Sadly, due to my unstable sugar levels, we miscarried in the first trimester. I can't put into words how that felt.  I felt like such a failure; we'd done our very best, but our very best brought us heartache like we'd never known.  Throughout all the appointments, tests, scripts, happiness and sadness, Chris was my rock and always there for me.  I kind of waited for him to just get tired of it all and leave but he never did.When we married in 2006, I didn't realise I was pregnant again.  I found out just before we suffered yet another loss.  After the third miscarriage, the emotional pain had taken its toll.  I couldn't handle any more disappointment and grief.  I decided the doctors were right - it was going to be next to impossible for us to have children and I was done. During the following months a specialist in Mackay prescribed me a new and better insulin and referred me to an opthamologist (a diabetic eye care specialist).  There I was diagnosed with diabetic retinopathy, a condition that damages the blood vessels inside the retina leading to vision loss and blindness.  The procedure to correct this would prove to be both painful and costly.We took several trips from Mackay to Brisbane for laser eye surgery and a victrectomy (surgery to remove vitreous humor from the eye).  It took months of pain and eyecare. I was completely reliant on Chris to get me to doctors' appointments as I couldn't drive.  Even getting around the house was difficult and I needed help with just about everything.  Still, Chris was there for me.While all this was going on, I fell pregnant yet again.  I didn't allow myself to get excited this time as I was certain it would end the same way as before. However, after four months, I started to believe that maybe the newly prescribed insulin was keeping my blood sugar levels in check and this pregnancy was going to last!  We had finally made it this far!  We made the decision to move back to Dalby to be closer to family and to the medical treatment I was recieving in Brisbane. At 28 weeks, my health began to waiver.  My blood pressure went through the roof, so high that it alone should have killed me.  As I recall, it was 240/160!  The staff at Toowoomba Hospital tried for two days to stabilise my pre-eclemspia to no avail.  I was transferred to the Mater Hospital in Brisbane where they informed me upon arrival and observation that at only 28 weeks and five days gestation our baby was to be born via emergency cesarean.  I was terrified.  How could he make it?  How could he possibly survive?When Noah was born on the 8th of October 2009, he was immediately rushed to the Special Care Unit and attached to the various machines that would give him his only chance of survival.  I was taken to the Intensive Care Unit where I was stabilised for two weeks. All I had was a photograph of my baby until I was well enough to be wheeled down to see my tiny boy.  When I look back on the day it finally happened, I feel so overwhelmed.  I was elated, but because of my eye surgeries, I could barely see him.  It didn't matter though because he was alive!  All 1.2 kilos of him, fighting to survive.Over the next three months, Noah stayed in the special care unit and day by day, grew stronger. Chris and I learned how to care for our premature baby who still relied on oxygen and a nasal tube for feeding.  Christmas of that year, I got the most amazing gift of all - we got to bring our miracle home.  Although he still required oxygen and suffered chronic lung disease, he was home...with us. Noah remained on oxygen for the first seven months of his life.  Chris and I had to carry the oxygen tanks everywhere we went until his lungs grew strong enough. Our little boy had bettered the odds!  Throughout all the doctors, peadiatricians, physiotherapists and sleep studies appointments he had along the way, Noah was diagnosed with spastic diplegia, a type of cerebral palsy that mainly affects the mobility of the lower half of his body.  Months of physiotherapy was required and when Noah started walking despite the odds stacked against him, I was so proud!  I have drawn all of my strength and inspiration from watching my boy defy the doctors' predictions.Shortly after Noah's first birthday we received one hell of a shock when we discovered we were expecting...TWINS!  I was already considered high risk due to my own health and previous complications during pregnancy and birth and now I was carrying twins, doubling the load on my body.  Despite all these factors I remained stable until I reached 24 weeks.  Again I was diagnosed with pre-eclampsia and admitted to the Brisbane Mater Hospital where they are equipped to handle premature twins if I went into early labour.  Chris, Noah and I stay at the Ronald McDonald house until I went into labour at 31 weeks.  Unable to stop the labour, another emergency cesarean was performed.During the surgery, I lost over two litres of blood, flat-lined, was resuscitated and required a blood transfusion.  But in between all the drama, I actually got to hold Phoebe, one of my twin girls.  It was an experience I had missed out on two out of three times. Emily was rushed to the neonatal incubator.  I managed to recover in the Intensive Care Unit and my baby girls, although premature, were in good health.  However, throughout my pregnancy my kidney function began to deteriorate.I handled life okay for the first few months, but eventually diabetes, high blood pressure, newborn twins, a child with cerebral palsy and waning kidney function became too much for me and I realised I needed help.  Once again, Chris was there for me.  Still.  He stopped working and stayed home to help me manage the family and my health.  A few months later, a career opportunity arose for Chris back near Mackay so we packed up again and headed north.We settled into our new life and home in Mackay and Chris was doing well in his job.  The only downfall was he had to travel three and a half hours to work and worked ten days away at a time.  So I was left in a new town without a vehicle, three children under three, managing Noah's CP, the twins' teething and of course, my own health.  I struggled for a year and a half before we decided a move to Moranbah, nearer to where Chris worked would make life easier.  Not only was it cheaper living, it also meant Chris could come home every day and be home sooner if I needed him urgently.It was a good decision as I had begun having dizzy spells from diminishing iron levels.  Follow-up tests were done and I was sent to a renal specialist.  Further testing showed my kidney function was as low as 17%.  When I was given this news it felt like something out of the movies.  Everything went quiet.  I could see the doctor speaking, the kids playing on the office floor, Chris looking at me and holding my hand, but there was no sound.  There was just this raw fear and uncertainty.   And millions of questions.  I remember being so, so scared.I was informed that while my kidney function would continue to drop, I would have to wait until it dropped to 10% before I could start dialysis.  By the time it got that low I was basically bedridden.  It actually turned out to be at 6% before I had my first procedure for hemodialysis, which involved having a catheter inserted into my neck, across my lungs and resting on my heart to clean and filter my blood.The next day I had to go under anaesthesia to have the peritoneal dialysis catheter operation.  What was meant to be a routine day operation ended with me spending a week in hospital from a bleeding complication.  For two and a half days I bled out.  The staff tried to apply (excruciating!) pressure to stem the blood flow, otherwise another operation would've been necessary.  I was so anaemic that I needed an iron infusion before going home.PD (peritoneal dialysis) was my preferred method of treatment for renal failure as I had more freedom with my diet and busy lifestyle and I could do it anywhere as long as it was sterile. A PET test also confirmed it as the best method for me as the membrane where the fluid sits likes to be wet. Renal failure occurs when the kidneys can no longer adequately filter waste products from the blood.  But the catheter for PD had to be in place for six weeks before it could be used.  Meanwhile, it was necessary for me to continue to endure HD (hemodialysis) because the Home Renal Unit in Mackay wasn't going to open until after the new year and I was so ill that I couldn't go without treatment any longer.The HD meant Chris and I had to drive into Mackay - a three hour drive, have dialysis (five hours) then turn around and drive the three hours home again.  We did this every two days for three months.  The sheer expense of it all was crippling.  I also had a reaction to the HD;  while my blood was being filtered by the machine, my blood pressure would skyrocket, resulting in a migraine-like headache.  Once the HD was done and I emptied my bladder, my blood pressure would return to normal.  There was nothing to be done about it, it was just an individual reaction my body had to the treatment.Finally the week long training for managing my own PD came.  This was done in Mackay so we drove the kids up to Townsville to meet with family who took them to stay in Cairns, while Chris and I learnt everything about doing PD at home.  The PD I do involves four bag exchanges a day, 4-6 hours apart.  The last dwell is at around 11 pm and stays in my stomach until around 8.30 am.  I have had to do this every day for the last seven months no matter how shitty I feel or what else is going on.Two weeks into my home PD, I received a call from my transplant co-ordinator/surgeon at the Westmead Hospital in Sydney. They wanted to see me to assess the possibility of a dual kidney and pancreas transplant!  I had been working towards this appointment for the past couple of months.  Many blood tests, scans, x-rays and reports from all of my specialists were needed to prove that I was a good candidate for transplant surgery.For a long time I'd been drawing strength from the prospect of this appointment but in the days leading up to this, a dear friend of mine who also suffered from Type 1 diabetes slipped into a coma for the last time after a long and difficult battle.  He was the only person I could talk to and know that he truly understood what I was going through as he had dealt with and suffered through it all already.  When he passed, I felt guilty as I was going through the motions of receiving organs that could've saved his life.  I felt so torn because on one hand, I wanted to go and show my respects but on the other I felt the best way to honour him was to attend the appointment.  To have a chance at a normal life.  I'm sure that's what he would have wanted.So I met with one of the surgeons and finalised all the paperwork.  They checked me inside and out and decided I was a suitable candidate for the transplant.  Words cannot describe how that felt.  I was on the transplant list!  I felt a mixture of excitement, fear and hope.  Hope for a brighter, healthier, more normal future for me and my family.  For the next three months everything went well.  I attended regular renal specialist and endocrinologist appointments with no problems, so we decided to treat the kids to a holiday in Cairns. It was wonderful! The night before we headed home, I woke in the night with pains in my chest and had trouble breathing.  I dealt with it all night, thinking it was a bad case of heartburn but by morning it became unbearable and an ambulance was called.  My blood pressure was something like 240/160.  A whirlwind of scans followed.  My enzyme levels were checked and showed the presence of troponin, which meant I had in fact, suffered and survived a heart attack! They watched my levels for a few days and sent me for a cardiogram, then an angiogram.  They attempted the first angiogram in my wrist but all my veins were too flimsy so they had to try again through my groin.  A narrowing of my circumflex artery was discovered and I was told I would need a stint put in my heart. This meant I would be removed from the active transplant list.  My glimmer of hope was gone.  I was devastated at being removed from the waiting list.Initially, it was to be for twelve months but after speaking with my transplant team in Sydney and an adjustment in medication, it was changed to six months.  I continued with the medication following the stint operation and a stress test would then determine if I would then go back on the active transplant list. A few weeks later I had to be flown out of Moranbah to Mackay where I was diagnosed with, and treated for pericarditis (fluid around the heart).  Yet another week was spent in hospital and yet again, Chris was there for me like he'd always been.  He and the kids spent hours driving back and forth to the hospital to be with me.  In the following weeks I had an angina attack and also lost my paternal grandmother, which was a whole other kind of pain.On returning home from my grandmother's funeral down south, I was diagnosed with an extreme case of pneumonia and a collapsed lung with a remarkable amount of fluid around it.  To make it worse, I had a reaction to the pain medication and was unable to keep down any food or water.  The nausea was so terrible I couldn't even stomach smells or movement.  I lost eight kilograms in under a week! The opiate medication they then put me on virtually put me in a vegetative state but the nausea remained.  My only option was to go without the pain relief and just deal with the pain.To remove the fluid from my lung, a tube had to be inserted through my back and allowed to drain out.  This process took two days.  Then x-rays were taken to ensure the lung had recovered sufficiently and no more fluid had accumulated. I was in hospital for eleven days before I happily went home.  While a bad cough remained, I eased back into routine and was feeling okay for the first time in a while.  But after two weeks, I felt the familiar swooshing sensation in my chest and knew I'd have to return to hospital...again.

story:
In July of 2012, Ulises Flores was in a car accident that left him paralyzed from the waist down. Ever since then, he has been struggling to regain function and mobility in certain parts of his body.

Upon his return to the United States, Ulises found a rehabilitation center in San Diego called Project Walk. I invite you all to visit the website below in order to learn more about the program and their agenda.
http://www.projectwalk.org/

Although very helpful, Project Walk has proved to be quite expensive. Their budget information is provided below:

    Days Per Week: 2-4 Days Per Week

    Hours: 2-3 Hours Per Day

    Costs Hours: $110 Per Hour (hourly rates may vary per location)

    Client Recovery Materials: $300 (provides one year of access)

    Total: $440 - $1320 per week

Because of the progress that Ulises has shown, we want him to be able to continue at Project Walk as long as he needs. In order for that to be possible, we need the help of all friends and family. No contribution is too small. Believe it or not, even a dollar would help his cause. If you are not able to contribute, we ask you to share our link in order to create more awareness of Ulises' causes. If you do contribute, we thank you and also ask that you share our link.

Our goal does not reflect the maximum we want to receive. We provided the pricing information so that you could understand the situation and decide for yourself what to contribute. We want to leave it up to you.

Because Ulises is too proud to ask for any of our help, we ask for your discretion with the donations. Of course, he will find out eventually, but in the meantime, we ask that you not mention this to him. Even if he does not ask for it, Ulises needs our help. Now is our time to show what it truly means to be family and friends.

story: Earthcoco, Inc., a coconut products company with corporate offices in Santa Monica, CA and doing business in Eastern Samar, Philippines, urgently requests financial assistance to provide immediate relief for the survivors of Typhoon Haiyan. In alignment with Earthcoco's ethos, to be a responsible member of the community of East Samar, where we work and live, we ask for your help. Any size donation is gratefully accepted and tax-deductible. 100% of your donations will be used for emergency relief. Filipino- Americans with relatives on Samar can leave messages for them with us and we will do our best to pass them on. With gratitude. Joel Polis, VP Earthcoco, Inc.
